helpTopic.p: With the CORBA drawer in the Palette, you create and model your CORBA environment in CX.
The following elements are available in the CORBA drawer:

helpTopic.title: CORBA Elements
helpTopic.p: The following CORBA elements can be created using the palette:
To model a CORBA Enumeration, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Enumeration.
Add this element to an IDL File, Module or Interface in a diagram.
Name the Enumeration.
With the Enumeration selected, in the Properties View > Literals tab, add the literals to the enumeration.
ol.br: On the Literals tab, elements can be reordered.

helpTopic.p: To model a CORBA Array, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Array.
Add this element to an IDL File, Module or Interface in a diagram.
Name the Array.
With the Array selected in the Properties View > Stereotypes tab set the index property.
With the Array selected, in the Properties View > Attributes tab, add a public attribute named members.
Select the members attribute and in the Properties View > General tab set the type.

helpTopic.p: To model a CORBA Sequence, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Sequence.
Add this element to an IDL File, Module or Interface in a diagram.
Name the Sequence.
With the Sequence selected, in the Properties View > Attributes tab, add a public attribute named members.
Select the members attribute and in the Properties View > General tab set the type.

helpTopic.p: To model a CORBA Struct, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Struct.
Add this element to an IDL File, Module or Interface in a diagram.
Name the Struct.
With the Struct selected, in the Properties View > Attributes tab, add a public attribute named members.
Select the members attribute and in the Properties View > General tab set the type.
ol.br: On the Attributes tab, elements can be reordered.

helpTopic.p: To model a CORBA Typedef, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Typedef.
Add this element to an IDL File, Module or Interface in a diagram.
Name the Typedef.
Add the data type the Typedef represents.
From the CORBA drawer in the Palette, select Generalization and draw a link from the Typedef to the data type.

helpTopic.p: To model a CORBA Union, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Union.
Add this element to an IDL File, Module or Interface in a diagram.
Name the Union.
Add a new attribute called switchType to the Union and set the type to the data type you which to do the switch() on.
Create public attributes for each case statement. Set the Stereotype for these attributes to CORBACase.
Select each attribute other than switchType, open the Properties View > General tab and set the name property.
ol.br: The name represents the attribute name inside the case statement.
ol.li: Select each attribute other than switchType and open the Properties View > General tab and set the type property.
ol.br: The type represents the attribute type inside the case statement.
ol.li: Select each attribute other than switchType and open the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and set the label property to the value for the case.
ol.br: The label represents the value of the case. For example, if the label is set to BLUE, case BLUE: will be generated.

helpTopic.p: The following procedure details how to group constants together. These constants can then be moved anywhere inside the IDL File.

ol.li: In the Palette, select Constants.
Add this element to an IDL File, Module or Interface in a diagram.
Name the element.
Add public attributes to the element.
For each attribute open the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and set the stereotype to CORBAConstant.
For each attribute open the Properties View > General tab and set the type property.
ol.br: To reorder the attributes: right click the Exception element, select UML Properties and then click OwnedAttributes.

helpTopic.p: A constant may be added directly to an interface without the Constants element specified above.

ol.li: Add a public attribute to a CORBA Interface and name the attribute.
Select the attribute, open the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and set the stereotype to CORBAConstant.
Select the attribute, open the Properties View > General tab and set the type and value properties.

helpTopic.p: To model a CORBA Exception, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Exception.
Add this element to an IDL File, Module or Interface in a diagram.
Name the element.

helpTopic.p: To add attributes to the Exception:

ol.li: Add public attributes to the Exception element.
For each attribute, select the attribute, open the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and set the stereotype to CORBAConstant.
For each attribute open the open the Properties View > General tab and set the type.
ol.br: To reorder the attributes: right click the Exception element, select UML Properties and then click OwnedAttributes.

helpTopic.p: To seta CORBA Interface operation to raise an Exception:

ol.li: Right click the CORBA Interface operation and select UML Properties.
Click RaisedException and add an exiting Exception.

helpTopic.p: To model a CORBA Union, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Union.
Add this element to a Module.
With the Union selected, in the Properties View > Attributes tab.
Add a new attribute called switchType to the Union and set the type to CORBALong.

For each case statement you want to generate, you must add an attribute to the Union and apply the CORBACase stereotype to the attribute. To control the ordering of the case statements, right-click and select UML Properties, select ownedAttributes and use the arrows.

helpTopic.p: A CORBA Constant can be added at the interface or module level. To add a CORBA Constant at the interface level, add an attribute and set the Stereotype to CORBAConstant. To add a CORBA Constant at the module level, in the Palette, select Constant and drop this onto the module.

helpTopic.title: Resource Factories
helpTopic.p: The resource factory element is used to model the dynamic creation and tear down of resources. This element is responsible for the creation and tear down.
A resource factory component implements the resource factory interface. A resource factory can be created using the Component Creation Wizard.
To create a ResourceFactory component, do the following:

ol.li: To open the Component Wizard, right-click a Model or Package and select Add Zeligsoft > Component.
Type a Component Name and from the Type drop-down list, select ResourceFactory.
Click Finish.

helpTopic.p: Create relationships from the ResourceFactory structure realization to the Component types it creates. This defines all the component types the ResourceFactory can create. Do the following:

ol.li: Drag the component structure realization for each component controlled by the ResourceFactory, onto the ResourceFactory diagram.
In the Palette, open the SCA Application drawer and select SCAResourceFactoryDependency.
Use the SCAResourceFactoryDependency to connect the ResourceFactory to each component structure realization.

helpTopic.p: In the application specify which Resource component instances the ResourceFactory will create. This will be a subset of the components that were added to the ResourceFactory diagram above. Do the following:

ol.li: In the application select each component controlled by the ResourceFactory.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and select the resourcefactoryref property. Browse to the ResourceFactory part in the application.

helpTopic.title: DMD
helpTopic.p: The Domain element in the SCA Platform palette drawer maps to the Domain Manager Descriptor file. The Domain Manager Descriptor describes which services the Domain Manager connects to during startup. The elements include:

ul.li: Domain: specifies the properties of the Domain Manager Definition.
Domain Dependency link: used to link the Domain Manager structure realization to the Domain element.

helpTopic.p: To create a Domain:

ol.li: Open the diagram that has a Domain Manager.
In the Palette, select Domain and drop it onto the diagram.
In the Palette, select Domain Dependency and draw a link from the Domain to the DomainManager structure realization.

helpTopic.p: The DMD Service elements include:

ul.li: DMD Service: specifies the services the Domain Manager connects to.
DMD Service Link: used to link the Domain element to one or more DMD Service elements.

helpTopic.p: To create a DMD service:

ol.li: Open the diagram that has a Domain Manager.
In the Palette, select DMD Service and drop it onto the diagram. Name the DMD Service.
Select DMD Service and in the Properties View > Stereotypes tab, set the options for the DMD Service.
In the Palette, select DMD Service Link and draw a link from the Domain element to the DMD Service element.
Repeat for each additional service.

helpTopic.title: Connectors
helpTopic.p: A connection determines how components communicate act with one another. It specifies the relationship between the provider of an interface and the user of an interface.
A connector is a communication link between two ports or a port and a supports interface. The ports are compatible if:

ul.li: Both ports realize the same interface or the provides port interface is a subclass of the uses port interface.
One port's conjugation is the inverse of the other.

helpTopic.p: To define a connection in CX, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, click Connector.
In the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, select the first element in the relationship. If this is not a valid selection, a circle with a strike-through is displayed.
In the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, click and drag the connector to the second element in the relationship.
ol.p: Edit the name of the connector. You can also edit the connector properties in the Properties View.

helpTopic.p: To ensure that descriptor generation works for connections to supported interfaces, make sure you are connecting directly to the component.

helpTopic.title: Ports
helpTopic.p: A port identifies a source/producer (Uses Port) or a sink/consumer(Provides Port) for data and/or commands. A Port is defined by the Port Type. The port realizes all interfaces that the port type realizes and uses all the interfaces that the port type uses. In the SCA, a port type can only realize or use one interface and is unidirectional.
CX uses UML 2 notation to indicate the port interface direction. The interface's direction is called its "conjugation".

If you are creating a port on an application, an SCAExternal Port is created. If you are creating a port on any SCA component interface, an SCAPort is created. Note that nodes cannot have ports defined on the element border.
To create a Port Type, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select your model or package, right-click and from the pop-up menu select Add Zeligsoft > PortType.
In the Name field, type a name for the port type.
ol.br: The Inverse Name is automatically completed.
ol.li: Select a Provides Interface from the list.
Click Finish.

helpTopic.p: To create an interface during Port Type creation, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select your model, right-click and from the pop-up menu select Add Zeligsoft > PortType.
Click Create Interface and type an Interface Name.
Click Finish.

helpTopic.p: To create a port on a component interface, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Port.
In the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, click the border of the component interface to which you want to add a port.
From the pop-up menu, select Select Existing Element.
Search for or Browse to the PortType and click Finish.
ol.p: If you change the name of the port, the associated worker functions are updated with the new port name.
ol.li: In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab, and set the Kind property.

helpTopic.p: To create a Free Standing Port (FSP) do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select the appropriate FSP Port element.
Drop the element onto an Application or Node structure in a Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
From the pop-up menu, select Select Existing Element.
Search for or Browse to the PortType and click OK.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab, and set the properties that apply to the FSP type.

helpTopic.p: To create an external port, do the following:

ol.li: Create a port on an application border.
From the pop-up menu, select Select Existing Element.
Search for or Browse to the PortType and click OK.

helpTopic.p: With the external port configured, you can then generate an external port tag in the SAD. To ensure a description is displayed in the SAD, configure the description property on the port.
To invert the port conjugation, in the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, right-click the port and select the Inverse Port Type.
Once a port has been created, you can change it's PortType simply by dragging another PortType onto the port existing on the component interface.

helpTopic.title: Property Types
helpTopic.p: The following property type options are available in this drawer:
Use these property types to create and define SCA properties that are referenced from component SCA attributes in CX.

In the SCA, a property has a name and this property has the potential to be re-used across multiple devices and/or components. For example, MAX_THROUGHPUT or DECRYPT_KEY can be created and make the re-use of properties simpler and more convenient.

ol.li: Create a new Property on a Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
Select the property and in the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and set the kind and type. For allocation properties, set the action.
In a Zeligsoft Component Diagram, select an element, such as a component interface or component structure realization.
Right click the element and select Add SCA > SCA Property. This creates a component attribute with a stereotype of SCAProperty.
Select the attribute. In the Properties View > General tab click Select Type and browse for the property you created. Click OK.
Use the Properties View > Stereotypes tab to set the necessary properties such as mode.
ol.p: If the attribute is not displayed in the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, right-click the component and from the pop-up menu choose Filters > Show/Hide Compartment > Attribute Compartment.

helpTopic.title: Freestanding FindBy Ports
helpTopic.p: A Free Standing Port (FSP) models a port or a service that is dynamically discovered during runtime. The SCA uses dynamic port discovery in some of its connection specifications (findby, deviceusedbythiscomponentref, devicethatloadedthiscomponentref). The information on the port is used by the SCA Core Framework to locate an instance (component, device, core framework or service) or a port on an instance that adheres to the information on the FSP. This port is then used in the connection.

FSPs can be used in CX to model these connection specifications elegantly. Actual discovery of the ports is the responsibility of the SCA Core Framework. CX allows you to model all connections that are available according to the SCA standard. An FSP can model a uses or provides port or a supports interface.
In this drawer the following freestanding port (FSP) element options are available:

These FSPs can be described as: CX supports all connection types as given in the SCA, including the specification of connections via FindBy_DomainFinder as per section D.6.5.1.1.3.2 of the SCA domain profile. The domainfinder element is used to indicate to the CF ApplicationFactory the necessary information to find an object reference that is of specific type and may also be known by an optional name within the domain. The valid type attributes are filemanager, log, eventchannel, namingservice, servicename and servicetype. If a name attribute is not supplied, then the component reference returned is the CF DomainManager's FileManager or Naming Service corresponding to the type attribute provided. If a name attribute is not supplied and the type attribute has a value of log, then a null reference is returned. The type attribute value of eventchannel is used to specify the event channel to be used in the OE's CORBA Event Service for producing or consuming events. If the name attribute is not supplied and the type attribute has a value of eventchannel then the Incoming Domain Management event channel is used.
To create an FSP do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select the FSP that you want to create.
Drop the FSP onto the appropriate element in the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
From the pop-up menu, select Select Existing Element and Search or Browse for the Port Type you want to use.
Click OK.

helpTopic.p: Note: When modeling FSP DomainFinder-ServiceName or FSP DomainFinder-ServiceType the SCA 2.2.2 Extension preference must be set in Windows > Preferences > Zeligsoft > SCA.

helpTopic.title: Connecting to Event Channels
helpTopic.p: The SCA states that two event channels be present, Incoming DomainManager (IDM) and Outgoing DomainManager (ODM). Users can also create their own event channels. The instructions below describe how to connect to the IDM in a CX model.
SCA devices should write to the IDM when certain events happen (i.e. the device changes state). To model the device connected to the IDM, do the following:

ol.li: Import CosEventComm.idl into the model. This IDL is provided by the ORB supplier.
Create a PortType based on the CosEventComm/PushConsumer interface.
Add a uses port to the Device Component Interface based on the uses PushConsumer PortType. Set the port kind to data.
From the palette, add a "FSP DomainFinder-EventChannel" based on the provides PushConsumer PortType to the node.
Select the Free Standing Port (FSP). Select the Properties view, SCA tab. Set FindBy Type to FindBy. Set the Findby Element Name and Name to IDM_Channel.
Connect the Device uses port to the IDM_Channel FSP.
Validate SCA and generate.

helpTopic.title: FSP DTLTCR and DUBTCR
helpTopic.p: In the SCA Application drawer there are two options: FSP Device that Loaded or FSP Device Used By.

FSP Device that Loaded: the DeviceThatLoadedThisComponentRef (DTLTCR) is a type of FSP. A component port connects to the freestanding port. This kind of connection allows the Core Framework to locate the device that participates in the connection. Can be used to model a uses or provides port. The DTLTCR FSP provides information on how to discover a port at runtime by indicating which device loaded a specific component instance.

FSP Device Used By: the DeviceUsedByThisComponentRef (DUBTCR) is used a type of FSP. A component port connects to the freestanding port. This kind of connection allows the Core Framework to locate the device that participates in the connection. Can be used to model a uses or provides port. The DUBCTR FSP provides information on how to discover a port at runtime using the UsesDevice relationship. This connection is necessary for dynamic connections to devices that are not loadable.
To create an FSP Device do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select the FSP Device that you want to create.
Drop the FSP Device onto the appropriate element in the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
From the pop-up menu, select Select Existing Element and Search or Browse for the Port Type you want to use.
Click OK.

helpTopic.title: Component Interfaces
helpTopic.p: An SCA Component Interface maps to a SCD.xml file. A component interface can realize interfaces. Doing so implies the component will implement the behavior for these interfaces. The SCA specifies interfaces for a set of specialized components that provide the infrastructure for an SCA system domain.
Ports can be added to Component interfaces. Adding a provides port means the component will implement the behavior for the provides port interface.
To add a component interface that realizes a Resource interface, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Component Interface and drag onto the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
Type a Name for the element.
Add the Resource interface to the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
Connect the Component Interface to the Resource interface with an Interface Realization.

helpTopic.title: Components
helpTopic.p: A component represents a software module (source code, binary code, executable, library, etc.) with a well-defined interface. The interface of a component is represented by its ports and supports interfaces. Component implementations show compiler and run-time dependencies and represent a binary for a particular build environment.
Use the Component Wizard to create components.
To create a component, do the following:

ol.li: To open the Component Wizard, right-click a Model or Package and select Add Zeligsoft > Component.
Type a Component Name and from the Type drop-down list, select an option.
ol.p: All other fields in the wizard are optional but enabled.

The wizard will create a corresponding Package, Component Interface, Component Structure Realization, Implementation with Executable File Name, and Diagram with the appropriate relationships for the component. Using the Type drop-down list you can create the following: Resource, Resource Factory, Device, LoadableDevice, ExecutableDevice, AggregateDevice, Device Manager, and Domain Manager. To create a component without a supported interface, select None from the Type drop-down list. If you create an AggregateDevice, the provides port is automatically created and added to the diagram.

By default a suffix is appended to the component name for each element you create with the wizard. To disable this, deselect Use default. To edit the default values, select Windows > Preferences > Zeligsoft > SCA.

When you create a Component, the appropriate worker functions are added to the component structure realization. The worker function visibility is set to private. The component implementation Executable File Name is displayed when you select the code attribute in the Properties View for the Implementation.
ol.li: Click OK.

helpTopic.p: A component implementation link between the component implementation and the component structure realization is automatically created. A generalization is created between the component structure realization and the component interface.
The SCA requires that an Assembly Controller be identified. Any SCA compliant component instance can be the assembly controller. To create an assembly controller, do the following:

ol.li: Create a component named Controller and add this element to the application structure.
In the Properties View > Stereotype tab.
Configure the Controller property on the application structure.

helpTopic.p: You can edit the component worker operations: right-click the worker operation and select Open Editor.
To edit the configure_body and query_body attributes, do the following:

ol.li: Select the component and then select the property, for example DECRYPT_KEY:Key.
To edit the configure method for DECRYPT_KEY, right click on the property and select Open Editor > Configure.

helpTopic.title: Devices
helpTopic.p: The following device elements are available:

ul.li: Executable Device: according to the SCA (v 2.2.2) an executable device extends the LoadableDevice interface by adding execute and terminate behavior to a Device.
Loadable Device: according to the SCA (v 2.2.2) a loadable device extends the Device interface by adding software loading and unloading behavior to a Device.

Device: according to the SCA (v 2.2.2) a device is a type of Resource within the domain and has the requirements as stated in the Resource interface. This interface defines additional capabilities and attributes for any logical Device in the domain. A logical Device is a functional abstraction for a set (e.g., zero or more) of hardware devices

Aggregate Device: according to the SCA (v 2.2) an aggregate device provides aggregate behavior that can be used to add and remove Devices from an aggregate Device. This interface can be provided via inheritance or as a provides port for any Device that is capable of an aggregate relationship. Aggregated Devices use this interface to add or remove themselves from composite Devices when being created or torn-down.

helpTopic.p: The author attribute must be configured for all devices. The os_name and processor_name attributes must be configured for executable devices.

ol.li: In the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, select the device.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab.
Configure the appropriate attribute: author, os_name, or processor_name.

helpTopic.title: Services
helpTopic.p: The following Service Model elements are available:

ul.li: Service: according to the SCA (v 2.2.2) a service can be use for SCA and non-SCA services.

helpTopic.p: The Component Wizard can be used to create a service. However the RepositoryId must be set manually.

ol.li: Right click on a package and select Add CX > Component.
Select type Service from the drop down list.

helpTopic.p: Service can be created from the palette.

ol.li: Open a Component Diagram.
From the palette's Platform drawer select Service and drop it on the diagram.
Add Component Interface, implementation, ... the same as for a component or device.

helpTopic.p: Note: When modeling Services the SCA 2.2.2 Extension preference must be set in Windows > Preferences > Zeligsoft > SCA.

helpTopic.title: Applications
helpTopic.p: An executable software program may contain one or more modules. The executable software exhibits pre-determined functionality. In COE an application is created by assembling a set of components and providing connections between compatible ports (formal interfaces) on adjacent components. Using Model Driven Design (MDD) techniques, individual components and the overall application model can be validated for correctness at any point in the development process.
An application is a set of components in a communicating architecture. An SCA application can have an unlimited number of component instances.
To create an SCA Application, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette select Application from the SCA Application drawer and drop it onto a Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
Select the Structure compartment on the Application and resize.
Component structure realizations can be dragged from the Project Explorer to the Application structure to create component instances (parts).

helpTopic.title: Nodes
helpTopic.p: A node consists of one device manager and a set of one or more hardware devices. A node contains one or more logical abstractions of physical hardware elements. A node can contain one or more devices and their connections. One of these devices needs to be an executable device. The content of the node defines the information in the DCD.

In UML modeling, nodes are model elements that represent the computational resources of a system, such as personal computers, sensors, printing devices, and servers. Nodes can be interconnected by using communication paths to describe network structures.
A node can be visualized as the logical abstraction of a hardware board that can be added or removed from the system.

You must define the device manager for each node. Using the Palette, create a device manager and then in Project Explorer, drag the device manager on to the node. Optionally, you can configure a file manager and SCAlog for the node.
Once you have created a node, use the Properties View to define the namingservice property for the node. Set this property to the Domain Manager you created.

helpTopic.title: Platforms
helpTopic.p: A platform is a set of nodes under the control of a single domain manager. A platform can contain one or more nodes, one of these nodes needs to contain a domain manager. The content of the platform is generated into the complete device profile
A platform is a modeling entity introduced by CX. The SCA equivalent of the platform is the entire set of DCDs that comprise the Domain.

Typical platform layers include a hardware layer composed of different types of processors (GPP, DSP, FPGA), memory buses, and inter connections, and the RTOS layer and middleware layers that provide services to application components. Similarly to applications, platform layers can be individually defined in a component-based manner.

You must define the domain manager for each platform. Using the Palette or Component Wizard, create a domain manager and then in Project Explorer, drag the domain manager on to the platform. Optionally, you can configure a file manager and SCAlog for the platform.

helpTopic.title: Managers
helpTopic.p: There are two elements available: Device Manager and Domain Manager.

According to the SCA (v. 2.2.2), a device manager is used to manage a set of logical devices and services. The device manager is responsible for the creation of logical devices and launching service applications on these logical devices. There is one device manager per DCD.

According to SCA (v. 2.2.2), a domain manager manages the software applications, applicationfactories, hardware devices (represented by software devices) and device managers within the system. Device are allocated to one or more hardware devices by the domain manager. There is one domain manager in the system.
You can use the Component Wizard to automatically create Device Managers and Domain Managers. In the wizard, use the Type drop-down list to select the appropriate element.
To define the DMD elements, do the following:

ol.li: Select the Domain element and drop it onto the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
Name the element.
In the Palette, select the Domain Dependency and link from the Domain to the Domain Manager element.
In the Palette, select the DMD Service and drop this element onto the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
Name this element.
In the Palette, select the DMD Service Link and link from Domain to DMD Service.
In the Palette, select the Component Implementation and link from Domain Manager to DMD Service.
In the diagram, select DMD Service.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and configure the following mandatory properties: findbyName to DMD_Serv, findbyType to 0-NamingService, and usesidentifier.
Save the model.

helpTopic.title: Uses Devices
helpTopic.p: This element is used to specify dynamic connections using DUBTCR FindBy ports. This element is needed because not all devices are loadable or executable.

A Uses Device is a requirement of something from a device - it documents that a component needs the device. This is different then 'depends on device'. This relationship can later be used to configure connections.
The source for this element is a definition or implementation. The element target is an allocation property.
A Uses Device can be defined on a component or device definition or implementation and points to one or more allocation properties on a definition or implementation.
To create a uses device, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, expand the SCA Platform drawer and select UsesDevice.
Drop the element onto the diagram and name the element.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and set the type.
Create an Implementation Artifact and name the element.
In the Palette, select UsesDevice Dependency and in the diagram, connect the Component structure realization or Implementation Artifact to the UsesDevice.
Add one or more allocation properties to the diagram.
Draw a Property Dependency from a UsesDevice to the allocation property
Set the value for the Property Dependency

helpTopic.p: This element is used to specify dependencies between a UsesDevice element and one or more allocation properties.
To define a uses device dependency, do the following:

ol.li: Add a UsesDevice to the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and configure the Type property.
In the Palette, select UsesDevice Dependency and connect either a component structure realization or an implementation to the UsesDevice element.
Add one or more allocation property references to the diagram.
For each allocation property, add a Property Dependency from a UsesDevice element to the allocation property.
Set a value for each Property Dependency.

helpTopic.title: Implementation Artifacts
helpTopic.p: Artifacts represent elements such as: executable files, libraries, and databases. The implementation artifact concerns the binary code that represents a component or device for a specific operating environment. Think of this as the executable or shared library that gets loaded to the target platform.
To create a monolithic implementation, do the following:

ol.li: In the Palette, select Implementation Artifact and drop the element onto the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
In the Palette, select Component Implementation and connect the component implementation to the component structure realization.
Configure the implementation properties such as Programming Language, Code, Compiler, and Run-Time.
The implementation artifact requires at least one of the following dependencies to be defined: Operating System, Processor, SoftPkgRef or PropertyReferenceDependency.

helpTopic.p: Used to connect a component implementation to a component structure realization. A component structure realization may be referenced by more than one component realization.

helpTopic.title: SCA Port Libraries
helpTopic.p: Shared libraries are used when the build configuration specifies options for shared libraries. So instead of creating static libraries for each Port, framework, etc, a shared library is created and the executable is linked with these. This means that the shared libraries have to be on the library path for the given target platform.
SCAPortLibraries can be modeled in CX and then referenced as a software package reference dependency. This specifies a Software Package Dependency (SPD) to the shared library.
For example, create a SCAPortLibrary component named SCAPortLibrary with an implementation for Linux:

ol.li: Create a package named SharedLibraries.
Right click on the SharedLibraries package and select Add Diagram > Zeligsoft Component Diagram Name the diagram SharedLibaries_Diag.
In the Application Palette, select Port Library and drop this element onto SharedLibaries _Diag.
Name the element SCAPortLibrary.
In the Properties View > SCA tab, deselect SCA Compliant.
Add an Implementation Artifact to the SharedLibaries_Diag and name it SCAPortLibrary_linux. Draw a Component Implementation link from the implementation to the SCAPortLibrary.
Select the implementation. In the Properties View > SCA tab open the Code and name the file libScaPortLibrary.so. Note that the Port Library file name must have the appropriate extension.
Right click on the implementation and select a build configuration for shared libraries (i.e. linux_x86_gcc_zcf100_sca22_omni410_build_sharedlibs)
Add any necessary dependencies to the SharedLibaries_Diag and draw the appropriate dependency links from the SCAPortLibrary_linux implementation to the dependencies.
SCA validate.

helpTopic.p: To use the shared library draw Resource Dependency from one or more component or device implementations to the SCAPortLibrary. The SCAPortLibrary requires an implementation that uses the same build configuration as the source of the Resource Dependency.

ol.li: Open a component or device diagram and drag the SCAPortLibrary onto the diagram.
Draw a Resource Dependency from the component or device implementation to the SCAPortLibrary.
Generate Source.

helpTopic.p: The SCAPortLibrary will contain the ports and interfaces needed by all devices and components that reference the SCAPortLibrary and have an implementation that matches the SCAPortLibrary implementation.

helpTopic.title: Libraries
helpTopic.p: Libraries can be modeled in CX and then referenced as a software package reference dependency. This specifies a dependency to a Software Package (SPD) to the library.
For example, create a SoftPkg library component named CryptoLib:

ol.li: Create a package named Libraries.
Right click on the Libraries package and select Add Diagram > Zeligsoft Component Diagram Name the diagram Libaries_Diag.
In the Palette, select Library and drop this element onto Libraries_Diag.
Name the element CryptoLib.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and set isSCACompliant to False.
In the Palette, select Component Interface and drop this element onto Libaries_Diag. Name the element CryptoLib_CI.
Draw a Generalization from CryptoLib to CryptoLib_CI.
In the Palette, select Implementation Artifact and drop this element onto the diagram. Name this element CryptoLib_Linux.
Select CryptoLib_Linux and in the Properties View > Stereotypes tab. Set code values file to cryptolib.so and type to SharedLibrary.
Use the Palette to draw a Component Implementation link from the CryptoLib_Linux implementation to the CryptoLib component.
From the Palette, add OS and Processor elements to the Libraries_Diag diagram.
Add OS and Processor links.

helpTopic.title: Dependencies
helpTopic.p: There are four dependency options available: Operating System, Processor, Property Dependency and Resource Dependency.
An Operating System dependency states that an implementation needs a certain Operating System.

ol.li: From the Palette select Operating System and drop it onto a SCA Component Diagram.
Name the Operating System element and in the Properties View > Stereotypes tab set the OS version. This element can be created once and reused.
Drag the Operating System element from the Project Explorer onto a SCA Component Diagram containing a component implementation.
From the Palette draw an OS Link from the component implementation to the Operating System element.

helpTopic.p: A Processor dependency states that an implementation needs a certain Processor.

ol.li: From the Palette select Processor and drop it onto a SCA Component Diagram.
Name the Processor element. This element can be created once and reused.
Drag the Processor element from the Project Explorer onto a SCA Component Diagram containing a component implementation.
From the Palette draw a Processor Link from the component implementation to the Processor element.

helpTopic.p: Use Property Dependency to represent a PropertyRef dependency. The Property Dependency is used to express a need from an implementation artifact to an allocation property. To add a Property Dependency, do the following:

ol.li: In the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, create a Primitive Property Type.
ol.br: Allocation properties can only be primitive types.
ol.li: In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab and set the kind property to allocation.
Open a Zeligsoft Component Diagram containing an Implementation Artifact.
In the Palette select Property Dependency and draw a link from the Implementation Artifact to the Primitive Property Type allocation property.

helpTopic.p: Use Resource Dependency to represent a softpkgref dependency. The Resource Dependency is used to specify a dependency to a software package. To add a Resource Dependency, do the following:

ol.li: In the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, create a Library.
ol.br: Add an implementation and any necessary dependencies.
ol.li: Open a Zeligsoft Component Diagram containing a Component Implementation Artifact.
Drag the Library structure realization onto the diagram.
In the Palette, select Resource Dependency.
Draw a connection from the the Implementation Artifact to the Library.
ol.p: Optionally in the Properties View > Stereotypes tab, define the SCAResourceDependency property of implementation to a specific library implementation.

helpTopic.title: Operating Systems
helpTopic.p: Use this element to define the supported operating system(s) in your model. These are then used as Operating System dependencies for your implementations. You can have multiple supported operating systems. Use the OS Link element to connect the component to the operating system.
Use this element to connect the component implementation to the required operating system which defines the implementation dependency.

helpTopic.title: Processors
helpTopic.p: Use this element to define the supported processor(s) in your model. These are then used as Processor dependencies for your implementations. You can have multiple supported processors.
Use this element to connect the component implementation to the required processor which defines the processor dependency.

helpTopic.title: Implementation Options
helpTopic.p: There are three optional elements available from the palette for defining implementations. These elements can be reused and are:

ul.li: Programming Language: use this element to define the type of programming language used to build the component implementation. See D.2.1.6.6 in SCA 2.2.2.
Compiler: use this element to define the compiler used to build the software component being described by the softpkg element. See D.2.1.6.4 in SCA 2.2.2.
Run-Time: use this element to define the run-time system.

helpTopic.p: There are three link options available: Programming Language Link, Compiler Link, and Run-time Link.
Use these elements to connect the component implementation to the element.

Implementations also have an optional language option that can be set. This defines the hummanlanguage specified in section D.2.1.6.6 in SCA 2.2. To set this property, select the implementation and open the Properties View > Stereotypes tab.

helpTopic.title: IDL Files
helpTopic.p: This element is used to represent the IDL file. Modules and interfaces and other IDL constructs are within these files.

Each IDL File has an option called location. You need to configure the location of the IDL file if you choose to reference an existing IDL file. If you wish to generate the IDL file from CX or Copy external IDL into the generated source folder, this field is ignored. This applies to both the Core Framework IDL file and user-defined IDL files.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select the IDL file folder.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab.
Define the location property. For example, the CF IDL file element location is set to $(CF_FILE_LOCATION)
Select Window > Preferences and expand General > Workspace > Linked Resources. Add a path variable and set the value to the location of the external IDL file.

helpTopic.p: This palette element is used to show a relationship between IDL files. It shows that one IDL file is including other IDL files and creates a #include statement when generating the IDL file.

helpTopic.title: Interfaces
helpTopic.p: Client-server relationships are set up by making connections between component ports. In an SCA-compliant implementation, these connections are made using CORBA interfaces.

An interface is the subject of an IDL definition. It may have attributes and/or operations. Operations may have parameters and return values. An interface may be specified in the SCA or be component-specific. SCA-specific interfaces are classified conceptually as either base application, control or service interfaces. The interfaces are used in the definition of supports interfaces and uses and provides ports.
To add attributes and/or operations to an interface, use the Properties View, select the Attributes or Operations tab, right-click and select Add.

helpTopic.title: Modules
helpTopic.p: This palette element represents a CORBA module, typically contained within an IDL file. A CORBA module can span multiple IDL files and an IDL file can contain more than one CORBA module. These modules are used to create namespaces.

helpTopic.title: Packages
helpTopic.p: Packages are used to group model elements. A package can contain multiple different element types. You can use packages to organize your model to enable easier visibility and understanding of model elements. Packages can also be used to model the system architecture, with packages representing different layers. Additionally, the use of packages can make it simpler and faster for you to find elements in the Project Explorer. Packages can have an unlimited number of sub-packages.
Packages are a good way of organizing your model for validation purposes as well. Validating a package also validates everything contained within the package.

helpTopic.title: Interfaces
helpTopic.p: The supported interface of an SCA-compliant component must conform to IDL definitions specified in the SCA. The implementation of a supported interface must also behave according to SCA specifications. The supported interface relates to the housekeeping functions of a component. The SCA specifies these "housekeeping" functions for a set of specialized components that provide the infrastructure for an SCA system domain. The SCA constrains the values that the supported interface can have. An interface is typically contained with in a CORBA module.

The SCA interface is responsible for managing the executable resources: Resource, ResourceFactory (Port, LifeCycle, TestableObject, PropertySet, PortSupplier), Device, ExecutableDevice, LoadableDevice and AggegrateDevice.

helpTopic.title: Generalizations
helpTopic.p: A generalization realizes the structural elements of the component. It realizes this in either structure, code (operations), statemachines, mathematical functions or other concepts as defined in the domain.

This generalization should be platform independent. That is, able to support all intended platforms for a particular design. The component implementation can be used to add platform specifics if required.

When a generalization is added between a component and a component interface, the methods on the provides port interfaces are displayed in the component structure realization. You can edit the default implementations of the worker methods. To do this, right-click the function and from the pop-up menu, select Open Editor to open an editor. These changes to the function will be added to the generated source code.

helpTopic.title: Interface Realizations
helpTopic.p: A component structure realization can realize a component interface. This is used to model interfaces realized by a component interface without using a port. For example, in the SCA we model the Resource interface using an interface realization rather than a port. This implies the component must realize the behavior for the Resource interface.
Provides PortTypes realize an interface. These provides ports implement the behavior for the interface which forwards the incoming message on to the component worker.

helpTopic.title: Editing and Viewing Elements
helpTopic.p: You can choose to edit and view elements using the Project Explorer, Zeligsoft Component Diagram, and the Properties View.
To edit or view an element, select the element in the Project Explorer or the Zeligsoft Component Diagram and then edit or view the element properties with the Properties View.

helpTopic.title: Deleting Elements
helpTopic.p: To delete an element from a diagram, right-click the element and from the pop-up menu select either: Delete from Diagram or Delete from Model.
A confirmation message is not displayed, so ensure you are deleting the correct element.
Note: from the Edit menu, you can select: Undo Delete from Model or Undo Delete from Diagram.
You can delete an element from the Project Explorer. However only Delete from Model is available from Project Explorer.

helpTopic.title: Packages
helpTopic.p: Packages are used to group model elements. A package can contain multiple different element type. You can use packages to organize your model to enable easier visibility and understanding of model elements. Packages can also be used to model the system architecture, with packages representing different layers. Additionally, the use of packages can make it simpler and faster for you to find elements in the Project Explorer. Packages can have an unlimited number of sub-packages.
Packages can be created from two locations: from the Project Explorer and from the Palette.
When you have created a package, you need to apply a profile and stereotype to the package:

ol.li: Select the package in either the Project Explorer or the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
In the Properties View > Profiles tab.
Click Apply Profile, select Zeligsoft Base Profile and click OK.
Select the Stereotypes tab, click Apply Stereotype, select a stereotype and click OK.

helpTopic.p: To add elements to a package, you can click and drag the elements within the Project Explorer onto the package or do the same within the Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
To show package contents, use the triangle symbols in the package to show the content and to navigate the package. The Project Explorer is updated to display package contents.

helpTopic.title: Port Types
helpTopic.p: PortTypes define how an interface will be used on a port. A PortType that uses an interface is assigned to uses ports. A PortType that realizes an interface is assigned to provides ports.
CX allows you to define the port types you need to effectively model your system.
To create a port type, do the following:

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select a package, right-click and from the pop-up menu select Add Zeligsoft > PortType.
In the Name field, type a name for the port type.
ol.br: The Inverse Name is automatically completed.
ol.li: Select a Provides Interface from the list.
ol.br: You can select existing interfaces or click Create Interface and type a new interface name.
ol.li: Click OK.
ol.br: When you create ports, you can select the port type you created.

helpTopic.title: Zeligsoft Diagrams
helpTopic.p: This section provides details on Zeligsoft Diagrams and how they are used to model in CX.

helpTopic.title: Adding Zeligsoft Diagrams
helpTopic.p: Use the Zeligsoft Component Diagram to do your modeling. When you create a project model, a Zeligsoft Component Diagram is created and opened.
To add a Zeligsoft diagram, follow these steps:

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, right click the Model or Package.
From the popup menu, select Add Diagram and select: Zeligsoft Component Diagram.
Type a logical name for the diagram.
ol.p: The diagram is added to the Project Explorer.

helpTopic.title: Deleting Zeligsoft Diagrams
helpTopic.p: When you delete a Zeligsoft diagram, the elements added to the diagram are not deleted.
In the Project Explorer, right-click the diagram and from the pop-up menu select Delete from Model.
A confirmation message is not displayed, so ensure you are deleting the correct element.
Note: from the Edit menu, you can select: Undo Delete from Model.

helpTopic.title: Properties
helpTopic.p: This section provides details about configuring element properties in CX.
Each element is completely customizable to meet the needs of your modeling environment. To define elements, use the Properties View.

When an element is created or selected, the Properties View is opened. The Properties View includes a number of sections that you use to define, edit and view element properties. These sections are described below.
Note: Some of the properties are specific to RSx, for information on these properties, refer to the RSx online documentation.
Name: specifies the name of the element. This is an editable field.
Visibility Options: specifies whether the element is public, private, protected, or a package.
This section allows you to customize the element and further define its behavior for your model.
Using the right-click pop-up menu you can do the following:

ul.li: Show an attribute in the Project Explorer

helpTopic.p: Using the right-click pop-up menu you can do the following:

ul.li: Show an operation in the Project Explorer

helpTopic.p: This section displays the assigned stereotype and profile for the element. Additionally, the stereotype properties are displayed.
You can edit the stereotype properties here. For details on a specific property, refer to the appropriate element topic in this section of the ProductName online help.
In this section you can define, edit, and view SCA, UML, and View properties.
For details on a specific SCA property, refer to the appropriate element topic in this section of the ProductName online help.
Use this section to write notes on the element that are not detailed elsewhere.
Constraints can be added and removed.
Relationships are displayed.
This section displays the SCA properties for the selected element. Use this section to define, edit, update, and view the SCA properties for your elements.
Use this section to customize the appearance of the element.
Literals can be applied to enumerations using this section.
Use this section to view the SCA and UML properties of the element or model.

helpTopic.title: Defining SCA Properties
helpTopic.p: There are different ways to define the elements in your model using SCA properties. Each element has associated mandatory and optional SCA properties that are configured in the Properties View. These properties are explained in detail in the main Properties section.

In addition to these mandatory and optional SCA properties, you can also create your own SCA properties for the elements in you model. These can be of configuration or allocation property type and these properties can be re-used in your model. This topic explains the workflow for creating and defining SCA properties.

ol.li: Create a data type (enumeration, primitive, struct, struct sequence, or test) and define the name.
In the Properties View > Stereotypes tab, set the data type action, kind, and type.
ol.br: This data type can be referenced by more than one SCA Property.

ol.li: Select an element (component, component interface, or component implementation) to which you want to add SCA properties.
Right-click the element and from the pop-up menu, select Add SCA > SCA Property.
A placeholder is added to the element. Type a name for the SCA property.
ol.p: Now that the SCA property has been created you can use it to reference data types within your model.
ol.li: Create a data type (enumeration, primitive, struct, struct sequence, or test).
In the Properties View > General tab click Type and then Search for or Browse for the data type you created above.
ol.p: This defines the type for the SCA property you created above.
ol.li: In the Properties View for the data type, select the General tab.
Ensure you set a the Default Value for the SCA Property.
ol.p: To identify the default value as a literal string, surround the value with " " (double quotes).

helpTopic.p: The following SCA properties are created for each SCA property you define:

ul.li: configure_body: use this property to add code to define the behavior of a specific property in the SCA.
description: describes the implementation. See D.2.1.6.2 in SCA 2.2.2.
mode: from the drop-down menu choose:
query_body: use this property to add code to define the behaviour of a specific property in the SCA.
range: click the ellipse button to specify minimum and maximum values.
runtest_body: this property is used when the Test Property Type is used. When you edit the Test source, this attribute is updated with the content.
units: this is an informational property, used to define the unit of the property type; for example, MIPS.

helpTopic.p: An SCA property can be overridden on an application or a node.

ol.li: Add the component or device containing the SCA property to your application or node.
Select the elements, right-click and from the pop-up menu, select SCA Properties.
ol.br: The SCA properties for the selected elements are displayed.
ol.li: In the Override SCA Properties window, you can override and edit the SCA property values. Simply select the value and make your changes. The default value is displayed and is indicated with (default).
ol.br: To revert to the default values, clear the value field. Note that you can only override SCA properties on the application or node - you cannot define or add new SCA properties.

helpTopic.title: SCA Application
helpTopic.p: This section provides SCA property details for each SCA element available in the SCA Application drawer of the Palette.

helpTopic.title: SCA Implementation
helpTopic.p: This section provides SCA property details for each SCA element available in the SCA Platform drawer of the Palette.

helpTopic.title: CORBA
helpTopic.p: This section provides additional property details for the CORBA elements available in the CORBA drawer of the Palette.

helpTopic.title: DMD
helpTopic.p: This topic explains the properties displayed in the Stereotypes section of the Properties View.
description: describes the implementation. See D.2.1.6.2 in SCA 2.2
id: uniquely identifies a specific implementation of the component and is a DCE UUID value. See D.2.1.6 in SCA 2.2.
findbyName: is the name that identifies the domain finder of object of type Type.
findbyType: one of filemanager, log, eventchannel, or namingservice. See D.6.5.1.1.3.2.

helpTopic.title: Interface
helpTopic.p: This topic explains the properties displayed in the Stereotypes section of the Properties View.
isLocal: defaults to False. Use the drop-down menu to select either True or False.

helpTopic.title: Applications
helpTopic.p: This topic explains the SCA properties displayed in the Stereotypes section of the Properties View.
controller: indicates the application part that is the main CF Resource controller for the assembly.
description: used to describe the element.
id: contains a DCE UUID generated by CX.
version: application version number. This option is relevant for SCA 2.2.2.

helpTopic.title: Component Interfaces
helpTopic.p: This topic explains the SCA properties displayed in the Stereotypes section of the Properties View.

corbaversion: is the version of the SCA. The default value is 2.2. This property can be configured system-wide using the Preferences window: Preferences > Zeligsoft > SCA. This is a mandatory property.
repositoryId: specifies the namespace of an IDL symbol.

helpTopic.title: Components
helpTopic.p: This topic explains the SCA properties displayed in the Stereotypes section of the Properties View.

author: provides information about who worked on a particular element or model. This property can be configured system-wide using the Preferences window: Preferences > Zeligsoft > SCA. This is a mandatory property.

class_Source: use this text field to add code that you want to add to the Worker class in the header file. When the code is generated, the field contents are added to the source file. You can also right click on the component and select Open Editor > Class.

cpp_Source: use this text field to add code that you want to add to the Worker cpp file. When the code is generated, the field contents are added to the source file. You can also right click on the component and select Open Editor > Implementation.
description: used to describe the element.

h_Source: use this text field to add code Worker header file. When the code is generated, the field contents are added to the source file. You can also right click on the component and select Open Editor > Header.
id: contains a DCE UUID generated by CX.
isSCACompliant: use the drop-down to set this property to True or False. By default this property is set to True.
title: an appropriate title.
version: component version number.

helpTopic.title: Ports
helpTopic.p: This topic explains the SCA properties displayed in the Stereotypes section of the Properties View.

kind: The port kind is set on port on the component interface. Click the ellipse button to open the Properties window. Then click the Insert New Enumeration button and use the drop-down menu to select an enumeration type. A kind may have more than one value. The enumeration type options are:

helpTopic.title: Implementation Artifacts
helpTopic.p: This topic explains the SCA properties displayed in the Stereotypes section of the Properties View.

helpTopic.title: Validation
helpTopic.p: CX has a robust and powerful validation engine. The validation the elements you add to your model are correct.
CX validation uses a containment hierarchy. That is, if you validate a package in CX, everything contained in the package is also validated.

CX assists you in ensuring that the generated XML complies with the SCA. The validation that CX performs saves you time since correct generation means that all pieces of the puzzle fit. Hence situations where incorrect XML is downloaded to an execution environment are avoided.
Using the Preferences window, you can disable the built-in validation rules.

Because CX uses the RSx validation process, the validation uses a containment hierarchy. With this in mind, ensure you have selected the correct element or model.

helpTopic.title: Implementing
helpTopic.p: Once your model has been created and validated, the next essential step is implementation. CX enables this to operate smoothly with its powerful code and descriptor generation functionality.

The code and descriptor generation capabilities of CX leverage the complete configuration in the model to determine the optimal code to generate for the applications and the communication between the connected elements. All of the information in the model is analyzed to determine the most optimized way to generate the code.
The use of COE methodology and code generation tools offers a decrease in development time and increase in the ability to re-use work and the associated code.

helpTopic.title: Code Generation
helpTopic.p: This section describes the completely customizable, out-of-the-box ProductName Code Generator and build environment and how SCA code generation works within CX.

The complete code base for an SCA-compliant component comprises two major parts: the SCA component code and the functional code. The component code manages all the SCA artifacts, ports, and properties through the CF::Resource interface. The functional code contains the signal processing and control behaviour for a component.

The complete code base for an SCA-compliant component comprises two major parts: the SCA component code and the functional code. The component code manages all the SCA artifacts, ports, and properties through the device interfaces: CF::Device, CF::LoadableDevice, CF::ExecutableDevice, and CF::AggregateDevice. The functional code contains the signal processing and control behaviour for a device.

As shown in Figure 1, the SCA component and device code is the outer shell of a component or device. It manages any CORBA calls that come in. It performs as much processing as necessary and passes call to the functional code when needed.
The functional code is non-CORBA code.

Code generation, as described in this document, means generation of the SCA component and device code, as well as the makefiles required to build this code. The functional code can be implemented in a separate workflow within RSx. The component and device code forwards calls to the functional code for handling where needed.
This diagram provides another view of the code generation process.

helpTopic.title: Generation Overview
helpTopic.p: Code generation works from the component or device definition. You can generate 100% of the code, including all of the code for the CF interface: CF::Resource (for components) or CF::Device, CF::LoadableDevice, CF::ExecutableDevice, or CF::AggregateDevice (for devices). You do not have to modify this code. You will also generate skeletons for the functional code, which you can extend.

Component code is the code that handles the CF::Resource interface. Device code is the code that handles the CF::Device, CF::LoadableDevice, CF::ExecutableDevice, or CF::AggregateDevice. The Interface code manages the uses and provides ports. The Functional code contains the actual signal processing or control behavior of the component or device. The Code Generator generates an empty (but compilable) skeleton for this functional code. You then extends the skeleton with your own code.

In Figure 1, the functional code (the orange part) can be seen as surrounded by the SCA component code (the grey part). The grey part is 100% generated from the Code Generator. You implement the orange part by extending the skeleton code. The same visual image can be applied to the SCA device code.
The generated source directory structure contains: functional code, component code, target specific code, and port code.

helpTopic.title: SCA Code Responsibilites
helpTopic.p: The Main function is used to start a component or device. It parses and manages executable parameters. It creates a CORBA object for the component or device and registers the element with the CORBA namingservice. It also starts the ORB, if required.

The main CORBA class (zceMyComponentServant) for a component implements CF::Resource , contains ports, properties, and interfaces. It also contains the code to manage them, including getPort, configure, and query.

The main CORBA class (zceMyDeviceServant) for a device implements CF::Device, CF::LoadableDevice, CF::ExecutableDevice, and CF::AggregateDevice , contains ports, properties, and interfaces. It also contains the code to manage them, including getPort, configure, and query.
All the information required to generate the code to implement this functionality is contained in the visual model.

The CF::Resource defines the external behaviour of an SCA component. For devices, there are four CF interfaces that define the external behaviour: CF::Device, CF::LoadableDevice, CF::ExecutableDevice, and CF::AggregateDevice.
CF::Resource standardizes how a component has to behave, including

CF::Resource states nothing about functional code, rather it triggers the functional code. The servant receives CORBA class for the CF::Resource interface and it triggers the functional code through standard C++ function calls.
These interfaces standardize how a device behaves, including:

The device interface states nothing about functional code, rather it triggers the functional code. The servant receives CORBA class for the interface and it triggers the functional code through standard C++ function calls.
CF::Resource::start is responsible for starting the processing. The component code manages the start. The component code then informs the functional code.

Ports define how the component or device interacts with the environment and thus how the functional code communicates. Ports have specified interfaces: Provides ports define incoming operations and Uses ports define outgoing operations.

The generated code manages the CORBA aspects of both provides and uses ports. Any incoming data from a CORBA call on a provides port is passed through C++ calls to the functional code. Any outgoing data is sent through a C++ call to the uses port object and the latter forwards to the receiver.
A component or device can have three types of properties:

ul.li: Configure properties define configurable and query-able parameters
ExecParam properties command line arguments during startup

helpTopic.p: CF::PropertySet::configure (in Properties configProperties) is responsible for writing values to properties. It passes a sequence of id (string) and value (any). The component or device code manages the configure, which includes verifying the id and any. It then forwards this data to the functional code through a C++ call to the function config_<propertyname>. The element code has already cast the data in the any field to the proper type and this is an input parameter to the config_<propertyname> function on the functional code.

Interfaces are used on ports and supports interfaces. The IDL needs to be compiled into C++ through the IDL2CPP provided with the ORB. The C++ needs to be compiled through the C++ compiler. This is all accomplished through the IDL_to_CPP > GenerateCPP and IDL_to_CPP > Compile_IDLCPP steps highlighted earlier.

helpTopic.title: Code Pattern
helpTopic.p: The following code pattern applies to both component and device code. The component CF Interface is CF::Resource. The device CF Interfaces are: CF::Device, CF::LoadableDevice, CF::ExecutableDevice, and CF::AggregateDevice.
The generated source code follows a strict pattern:
The Main class manages startup, including

ul.li: creating the CORBA object for the component or device
registering components or devices in the namingservice

helpTopic.p: You don't need to modify the Main class.
The Servant class manages the following:

ul.li: implements all of CF::Interface (inherits from POA_CF::Resource)
forwards calls to the worker when necessary

helpTopic.p: You don't need to modify the Servant class.
The Worker class manages the following:

ul.li: termination of CF::Interface operations, including user-defined additions to initialize, releaseObject, start, stop
runs config_<propertyid>, query_<propertyid>, which are correctly casted from the configure/query methods

helpTopic.p: The Provides port implements the CORBA servant for the interface defined on the port. It receives CORBA calls and forwards them to the worker through C++ calls. The worker inherits from an abstract interface to implement the functionality of the operations on the port. The Port class performs no functional processing. It provides the connection boundary.

The abstract interface that the worker inherits from is called zceMyModule_MyInterfaceHandle. It has operations MyInterface_MyOperation for every operation MyOperation on interface MyInterface in module MyModule. The operations have the same parameters as the functions definition in the IDL file, with the addition of one parameter (the first in the list), which is an integer portIdentifier. The portIdentifier parameter allows the user to identify which port a particular function call came in on. This can be done through an if-statement or a switch-statement for example. The switch-statement will provide better performance especially with a high volume of messages.
The worker inherits from this port handler class.

The Provides port has a user interface to the CORBA servant. It receives CORBA calls and forwards them to the worker. The worker method looks at the port identifier and then calls the appropriate method <portname>_<method>. This allows the components to support multiple provides ports of the same interface.

The Uses port implements a CORBA client. It receives calls from the worker and forwards them to the CORBA object on the other end of the connection. The uses port also implements the CF::Port interface as per the SCA standard. By default, the uses port only supports single connections. You need to modify the uses port class if multiple definitions are required.
The uses port is available as an attribute within the worker class (myPort_). You can make C++ calls on this object and the calls are directly translated into CORBA calls.
The class for the uses port can be found in <Source Directory>/ports/<Module>_<Interface>.

helpTopic.title: C++ Portable Exception Layer Macros
helpTopic.p: The Portable Exception Layer enables seamless cross-platform programming by providing C++-style exception handling on platforms where it is not supported. Code written with this layer works on platforms that support true exception handling as well as platforms that do not. Code will be compliant with the C++ mapping, on either true-exception or non-exception platforms, when these macros are used.

Files or modules which make use of the macros must include the scxCorbaExceptionMacros.h header file which is provided by a build configuration. A build configuration will support either true-exceptions or non-native exceptions, not both. It is therefore important to use a build configuration which is appropriate for the chosen environment.

helpTopic.title: Descriptor Generation
helpTopic.p: CX generates SCA-compliant XML descriptor files from the UML 2.0 model that you define. The XML is generated from the modeling elements, their connections, and the attributes of these model elements. CX creates all the XML descriptor files as specified in the Domain Profile:

CX generates the Software Assembly Descriptor for the application. It also generates the Software Component and Software Package Descriptors for each component contained in the application. If you have defined properties for the components, CX generates the Properties Descriptors, as well.

The CX user interface is intuitive: model settings are generated into their relevant descriptors. For example, the placement of component instances in an application and the connection of those components is generated into the Software Assembly Descriptor, while the component PackageAttributes are generated into the Software Package Descriptor.

helpTopic.title: Generating XML Descriptors
helpTopic.p: CX can validate and generate XML for all elements including nodes, applications, component and device structure realizations, platforms, and deployments.

ol.li: In the Zeligsoft Component Diagram, select and right-click the element.
From the pop-up menu, select CX Generate > Descriptors.
The Running Transformation window is displayed. If you are generating a large amount of descriptors, click Run in Background to run the process in the background.
ol.p: The SCA descriptors are added to the Project Explorer. You can view these files within RSx.

helpTopic.title: Shared Descriptor Files
helpTopic.p: Property-files (PRF) files can be shared by multiple model elements a practice frequently used because it saves time when creating XML files.

CX allows import of these shared XML files, which results in multiple model elements referring to the same XML files for generation. This results in correct XML if and only if the content of those files (and hence the content of the model elements) is the same. Different content for these model elements may lead to unexpected behavior. CX indicates shared XML files with an error to prevent possible problems.

As an example, say that after import, component A and B both share a property file. If A and B have the same properties, then this is fine. However, if you add a property to A, then the components generate a different property file. The final content of the XML property file depends on which component was generated last, which is undefined. CX indicates these XML files with an error.
Zeligsoft does not encourage the use of shared descriptor files.

helpTopic.title: Tutorials
helpTopic.p: The tutorials in this section provide you with a comprehensive introduction to working with CX. You will learn about element creation, property definition, validation, and generation. These tutorials will help you learn about the concepts fundamental to COE and CX.
