helpTopic.title: Tutorial 1: Learning the Basics
helpTopic.p: ProductName is the backbone of SCA development. Using components, UML 2.0, and domain specializations you can dynamically build and design systems. CX takes you to the next step by combining the model and the code for a true model driven development process. With CX you model structure and implementations to define SCA compliant applications and platforms. The validation feature takes things one step further, to ensure that SCA compliance is guaranteed.
In this introductory tutorial you will learn how to:

ul.li: create elements, including applications, components, ports, and connectors

helpTopic.h2: Create a new project and model
helpTopic.p: Models are saved in EMX format. A single project can have multiple models - you can use the elements from different models within one project. Additionally, you may want to have separate platform and application models. However, for simplicity, this tutorial will use just one model.

ol.li: From the File menu, select New > SCA Model Project.
In the Project Name field, type CXTutorial and click Next.
In the Model Name field, type CXTutorial_Model.
In the CDT Project Name field, type CXTutorial_Model_src and click Finish.

helpTopic.p: The model project is displayed in the Project Explorer. This model project folder contains a Diagrams folder and a Models folder. These folders are not real folders, in the file system. Rather, they provide a logical view of elements in your model. The Diagrams folder contains all the diagrams in your project.
In the Models folder, a modelConfiguration entry is listed in the Project Explorer. Use this to view and edit the model configuration.
CX preferences are organized into three categories: Modeling, SCA, and Validation.
In this section you will configure the Modeling and SCA preferences and review the default Validation preference settings.
The Modeling preferences include:

ul.li: Post-fix for Inverse Port Type: allows you to control how the inverse port type is named. By default this attribute is set to Inv.
Make location: location of the make application used to build applications. Type the location or click Browse.

helpTopic.p: The SCA preferences include the following:

ul.li: CORBA Version: the default value is 2.2. Ensure this attribute is configured to match your system.
Repository Version Identifier: the default value is 1.0.
Author properties: configure the Name, Company, and Webpage properties.
Component wizard options: configure the default executable file extension for elements created with the Component Creation Wizard.
SCA 2.2.2 Extension: select when modeling SCA 2.2.2 Extension elements. Enables SCA 2.2.2 Extension DTD files.

ol.li: From the Windows menu, select Preferences.
In the Preferences window, expand Spectra CX.
ol.p: The Modeling and Validation sections are displayed.
ol.li: To view the suffix for inverse PortType and Make location options, select Modeling. By default the inverse PortType option is enabled and set to Inv.
Select SCA to display the SCA preferences.
In the Author properties section, type your Name, Company, and Webpage information.
ol.p: The CORBA Version and Repository Version Identifier are configured with default values.
ol.li: Click Apply.
Review the Component options.
Select Validation and review the validation constraints. By default all constraints are enabled.
Click OK.

helpTopic.p: You can use packages to group or contain common elements and to help you better organize your elements.

ol.li: In Project Explorer, right-click on CXTutorial_Model and from the popup menu, select Add CX > Package.
Name the Package, TutorialApplication.
ol.p: The package is added to the Project Explorer.

helpTopic.p: You will use this package to "hold" or "contain" the elements you create in this tutorial.

A component represents a software module (source code, binary code, executable, DLL, etc.) with a well-defined interface. The interface of a component is represented by one or several interface elements that the component provides. Components are used to show compiler and run-time dependencies, as well as interface and calling dependencies among software modules.
Using the Component Wizard you will create a component and the corresponding associated component interface, implementation, package, and diagram.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select the TutorialApplication package.
To open the Component Wizard, right-click the TutorialApplication package and select Add CX > Component.
In the Component Name field, type Decryptor.
ol.br: All other fields in the wizard are optional but enabled.
The wizard will create a corresponding Component Interface, Implementation, Executable File, Package, and Diagram for the component.
ol.li: In the Component Interface, select Resource from the Type drop-down list.
Click Finish.
In the CX Component Diagram, select DecryptorInterface.
Select the Properties View > SCA tab. This is where SCA component property values can be viewed and/or set.
Create a second component, in the TutorialApplication package, named Filter.

helpTopic.p: The new elements are displayed on the diagram you created with the Component Wizard.
helpTopic.h2: Add User IDL to the Model
helpTopic.p: IDL is used to specify interfaces used for communication. PortTypes are then created from this IDL to specify how the interface is used (i.e. provides or uses ports). IDL may be modeled or imported.

ol.li: In Project Explorer, select CXTutorial_Model and create a new package called Communication.
In Project Explorer, select the Communication package, right-click and from the popup menu, select Add Diagram and select: CX Component Diagram.
Name the diagram, Communication.
In the Palette, expand the CORBA drawer and select IDL File.
Drop the element onto the new diagram. Name the element, DataFile.
This IDL file depends on CF.idl. In the Project Explorer drag CXTutorial_Model::CF_IDL::CF onto the Communication diagram.
In the Palette select IDL Include link and draw a link from the DataFile to CF on the Communication diagram. This will cause a #include <CF.idl> to be generated in the DataFile.idl file.
In the CORBA drawer, select Module and drop the element onto the diagram.
Name the element, Data.
In the CORBA drawer, select Interface and drop it onto the diagram.
Name the element, EncryptedData.
Create two more Interface elements and name them OpenData and ProcessedData.
In the Project Explorer, move the elements so that Data is in the DataFile element and that the three new Interfaces (EncryptedData, OpenData, and ProcessedData) are in the Data element.
Right-click on the Communication diagram and from the popup menu, select Filters > Show/Hide Relationships and then click OK.
ol.br: The containment relationships are now displayed on the diagram.
ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select EncryptedData.
In the Properties View > Operations tab.
Click the Insert New Operation button. Be careful to click the drop down arrow, rather than the button itself. This will reveal a menu from which you should select CORBA Operation
Create a new operation called pushEncryptedData.
In the Project Explorer, select pushEncryptedData.
In the Properties View > Parameters tab.
Click the Insert New Parameter button and create a parameter called pkt. Set the type for the new parameter to CF::OctetSequence and set the direction to in.
Repeat the above for OpenData. Create an operation called pushOpenData
Create a parameter of type CF::OctetSequence called pkt.
Repeat the above for ProcessedData. Create an operation called pushProcessedData and create a parameter of type CF::OctetSequence called pkt.
In the Project Explorer, right-click on DataFile and from the popup menu, select CX Generate > Generate IDL.
ol.br: A file CXTutorial_Model_src/idl/DataFile.idl is generated and displayed in the Project Explorer. Also, because DataFile.idl includes CF.idl which in turn includes PortTypes.idl, these two additional IDL files are also generated.

helpTopic.p: Note that the new CXTutorial_Model_src project has an error. This can be safely ignored for now. It occurs because the project is created as a CDT project but it does not yet contain a makefile. When we generate code later, a makefile will also be generated which will solve this error.

The port type defines how the interface is used as a port. The port realizes all interfaces that the port type realizes and uses all the interfaces that the port type uses. In the SCA, a port type can only realize or use one interface and is unidirectional.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, right-click the Communication package and choose Add CX > PortType.
In the Name field, type EncryptedData.
ol.br: Use the default Inverse Name.
ol.li: Select the EncryptedData Interface.
Click Finish.
Create two more port types named OpenData and ProcessedData. Select the appropriate interface for each one.

helpTopic.p: The new port type and the inverse port type are added to the Project Explorer in the Communication package.

Ports isolate a component from its environment and its environment from the component. Each port has one interface. Each port has a direction: provides or uses. CX uses UML 2.0 notation to indicate the port interface direction. The interface's direction is called its conjugation. SCA ports are unidirectional and support a single interface.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, open the Decryptor diagram you created with the Component Wizard.
ol.br: This diagram is in the CXTutorial_Model::TutorialApplication::Decryptor package.
The component, component interface and implementation are displayed.
ol.li: In the Palette, expand the SCA Application drawer.
Select Port and drop the port onto the Component Interface.
From the pop-up menu, select Select Existing Element.
Click Search and type EncryptedData.
Select the <<PortType>> EncryptedData and click OK.
Name the port dataIn.
ol.br: When naming a port, ensure the name indicates: how the component uses the environment (uses port) and how the environment uses the component (provides port). The key to successful use of ports is to name from the viewpoint of the component.
ol.li: With the dataIn port selected, goto the Properties View > SCA tab.
In the Kind field, click the Edit Kind.
In the Properties window, click Add New Kind.
Click in the Value field and from the drop-down list, select 0-data and click Close.
Create a uses port on the Decryptor component interface. Select <<PortType>> OpenDataInv and name the port dataOut. Set the Kind to Data.
In the Project Explorer, open the Filter diagram you created with the Component Wizard.
ol.br: This diagram is in the CXTutorial_Model::TutorialApplication::Filter package.
ol.li: Create a provides port on Filter component interface. Select <<PortType>> OpenData and name the port dataIn. Set the Kind to Data.
Create a uses port on the Filter component interface. Select <<PortType>> ProcessedDataInv and name the port dataOut. Set the Kind to 0-data.

helpTopic.p: An application is a set of components in a communicating architecture.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select the TutorialApplication package and from the right-click menu choose Add Diagram > CX Component Diagram.
Name the diagram, ApplicationDiagram.
In the Palette, expand the SCA Application drawer.
Select Application and drop the element on the CX Component Diagram.
Name the application TutorialApplication.
Select the application border and drag to resize the application to fill the whitespace.
In the Project Explorer, select the TutorialApplication::Decryptor::Decryptor component structural realization you created and drag it onto the application.
In the Project Explorer, select the TutorialApplication::Filter::Filter component structure realization you created and drag it onto the application.
Resize the components and position them evenly on the application.

helpTopic.p: Connections are used to show which elements communicate with each other. Uses ports connect to provides ports (or supports interface). Connectors can also be used with external ports. In this case, a uses port is connected to a uses port and a provides port is connected to a provides port.

When creating connections, keep in mind that all the elements and labels in the CX Component Diagram can be moved and resized. Additionally, you can control the font type, size and color to make the diagram more visually dynamic.

ol.li: Open the ApplicationDiagram.
In the Palette, expand the SCA Application drawer and select Connector.
Draw a connection from Decryptor dataOut port to Filter dataIn port.
Delete the connector name.

helpTopic.p: Applications can have external ports. These are created on the application's border using the same procedure as when creating internal ports.

ol.li: Create a port on TutorialApplication based on an existing element.
Search for ProcesssedData and select <<PortType>> ProcessedDataInv. Name the port, dataOut. The port is displayed on the border of TutorialApplication.
Draw a connection from the Filter dataOut port to the TutorialApplication dataOut port.
Delete the connector name.

helpTopic.p: On the toolbar, click the Save icon.

The validation process ensures that all SCA requirements are being met in your model, elements, or application.
To validate the TutorialApplication, do the following:

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select TutorialApplication. Right-click and from the pop-up menu, select SCA Validation.
ol.br: The validation process will run and any errors, warnings, or informational messages are displayed in the Problems View.
Four errors are returned by the validation process.

helpTopic.p: The following errors are returned (and will be fixed later):

ul.li: TutorialApplication property controller is required but has no value.
This error is related to not having defined an assembly controller.
DecryptorImpl requires at least one os, processor, property dependency or resource dependency.
This error indicates that further modeling is required on the DecryptorImpl element.
FilterImplImpl requires at least one os, processor, property dependency or resource dependency.
This error indicates that further modeling is required on the FilterImpl element.

helpTopic.p: In addition to the these four errors, produced by the model validation process, the following error can also be seen. This error can be ignored. CX is looking for a makefile to build source. Because we have not generated source and its makefiles this error appears.

One of the errors returned by validation indicated that an assembly controller is missing. The SCA requires that an assembly controller be identified. Any component instance in your model can be the assembly controller. To resolve this error, you will create a new component and then designate it as the assembly controller.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select the TutorialApplication package that you created in Tutorial 1.
Right-click on the element and select Add CX > Component.
In the Component Wizard, name the component AssemblyController and in the Type drop-down list, select Resource.
Click Finish.

Open the AssemblyController diagram and add two uses ports to the component interface. The ports should be of type <<PortType>> ResourceInv and be named decryptCtrl and filterCtrl. In the Properties View SCA Tab set the kind to Control on both ports.
In the Project Explorer, open the ApplicationDiagram diagram.
In the Project Explorer, select AssemblyController structural realization and drag it onto TutorialApplication.

In the Palette, select the Connector and connect the AssemblyController ports to the decryptor and filter. Note these connections should be made directly to the components, not their ports. Leave the connection names empty.
With the TutorialApplication selected, click the SCA tab in the Properties View.
In the controller field, click the edit button.
Choose the assemblyController part which is part of TutorialApplication, and click OK.
ol.p: This identifies the component as the assembly controller for the application.

helpTopic.p: To ensure that the error regarding the assembly controller, discovered in the earlier validation process, are fixed, validate the TutorialApplication again. You should now see the following errors (which will be fixed later):

ul.li: AssemblyControllerImpl requires at least one os, processor, property dependency or resource dependency.
DecryptorImpl requires at least one os, processor, property dependency or resource dependency.
FilterImplImpl requires at least one os, processor, property dependency or resource dependency.

helpTopic.p: Property types are essentially elements that can be re-used multiple times. Property types are used to define the elements in your model. There are a number of property types:

In the SCA, a property has a name and this property has the potential to be re-used across multiple devices and/or components. For example, MAX_THROUGHPUT or DECRYPT_KEY can be created and make the re-use of properties simpler and more convenient.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, right-click your CXTutorial_Model model and select Add CX > Package.
Name the package SCAProperties.
Right-click SCAProperties and select Add Diagram > CX Component Diagram.
Name the diagram SCAPropertiesDiagram.
In the Palette, expand the SCA Application drawer.
In the Property Types drop-down list, select Primitive Property Type.
Drop this element onto the CX Component Diagram.
Name the property Key.
In the Properties View > SCA tab.
Set the following attributes:
Save the model.

helpTopic.p: This property is now available to be applied to model elements.
Each component interface, component, instance or implementation can have several properties. Properties are used to provide extra information about the element they are associated with.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, open the Decryptor diagram. This is the diagram you created earlier with Component Wizard.
In the CX Component Diagram, select the Decryptor.
Right-click on Decryptor and from the pop-up menu, select Add CX > SCA Property.
Name the attribute DECRYPT_KEY.
Select the DECRYPT_KEY attribute and in the Properties View > SCA tab.
Click the Select Type button and choose the Key primitive property you created earlier.
Set the Value to abc123.

helpTopic.h2: Components and Devices: Definitions, Implementations, and Instances
helpTopic.p: A component or device's definition is its external interfaces and ports. A component or device's monolithic implementation is an implementation of the component's definition. This is usually associated with source code or an executable. Instances of either a component or device definition are added to an application or node. All definitions used must have at least one implementation.
Each definition needs one or more implementations.
The operating system and processor dependencies define which operating environment the component implementation needs to run or be loaded in.

ol.li: In CXTutorial_Model, create a package named SCADependencies, add a CX Component Diagram and name it Dependencies. Open this diagram.
In the Palette, expand the SCA Application drawer.
Select Operating System and drop this onto the Dependencies diagram. Name this element Linux.
In the Properties View > SCA tab and set the Version to 2.6. The Version should match the os_version allocation property set on the device to which this component will be deployed.
In the Palette select Processor and drop this onto the diagram. Name the element x86.

helpTopic.p: For each Component in your model, do the following:

ol.li: Open the component's associated CX Component Diagram.
Drag the Linux and x86 elements from the SCADependencies package onto the diagram.
In the Palette, select OS Link and connect the implementation to Linux.
In the Palette, select Processor Link and connect the implementation to x86.

helpTopic.p: A freestanding port (FSP) models how to find a port or a service during run-time. A supports interface, uses or provides port can be designated as a freestanding port.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, open the ApplicationDiagram diagram.
In the Palette, expand the SCA Application drawer.
Select FSP Device That Loaded and drop this element onto the application structure.
Select Existing Element and search for the Port Type (EncryptedData) you created in Tutorial 1.
Select <<PortType>> EncryptedDataInv and click OK.
Name the port dataSource.
Select the FSP and in the Properties View > SCA tab.
Set the part property to decryptor in the TutorialApplication.
Set the Findby Port Name property to dataSource. This is the name of the port to connect to on the platform.
In the Palette, select the Connector and connect the decryptor's dataIn port to the dataSource FSP.
Right-click on the dataSource FSP and select Add Note. Type: DTLTCR for Device That Loaded This Component Ref. Resize and move the note as necessary.

helpTopic.p: Select the TutorialApplication and validate again. The application should validate with no errors. Validating the application, also validates other components and elements that are used in the definition of the application.

helpTopic.title: Tutorial 3: Platform Development
helpTopic.p: This tutorial builds on Tutorial 1 and Tutorial 2. In this tutorial, you will learn some more advanced skills and concepts. You will learn about:
This tutorial assumes you have completed Tutorial 1 and Tutorial 2.
In Tutorial 2 you created the following elements:
In the Project Explorer expand the project and model you developed Tutorial 2.
The platform is divided into: devices, nodes, and platforms.

A device is an abstract software representation of a physical hardware element. Devices are the software view of the hardware element. These elements, allow a platform independent SCA model to include the platform view. Devices are very similar to components - you must configure the device's interfaces and ports.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select CXTutorial_Model and create a new package called Platform.
Right click on the Platform package and from the popup menu, select Add CX > Component.
Name the device Modem and set the Type to ExecutableDevice. Click Finish.
Add processor and OS dependencies from the SCADependencies diagram to the Modem diagram. Using the Palette, draw OS and Processor links.
Validate the Modem package and correct any errors.

helpTopic.h2: Create ports on the device interface
helpTopic.p: This is done the same way as you did on the component interface. You will reuse the portTypes you created when adding ports to component interfaces.

ol.li: Open the Modem diagram.
In the Palette, select Port and drop it onto the ModemInterface component interface.
From the menu, select Existing Element and search for EncryptedDataInv. Select <<PortType>> EncryptedDataInv and name the port dataSource.
Select the dataSource port and in the Properties View > SCA tab and set kind to data.

helpTopic.p: This is similar to defining the SCA properties on a component. An executable device has two properties: os_name and processor_name.

ol.li: Open Modem diagram.
Right click on the Modem structure realization and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the property os_name.
Select os_name and in the Properties View > SCA tab.
Click Edit Type and choose os_name. Set the Value to Linux.
Right click on the Modem structure realization and select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the property processor_name.
Select processor_name and in the Properties View > SCA tab.
Click Edit Type and choose processor_name. Set the Value to x86.
Save the model.

helpTopic.p: Allocation properties can be used to specify services from the device. For example, using allocation properties, you can define processing power and throughput for the device. When you define allocation properties, you have to set the action property: when set to external, this implies that the device manages the capacity using allocateCapacity and deallocateCapacity; any other setting indicates that the Core Framework manages the capacity.
SCA properties in CX are elements and as such can be reused.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer open CXTutorial_Model > SCAProperties > SCAPropertiesDiagram.
In the Palette, select Primitive Property Type and drop this element onto the diagram.
Name the element KIPS. In the Properties View > SCA tab.
Set the following properties:

ul.li: Action to Greater than or Equal

ol.li: Repeat this process for a second SCAPrimitive named Throughput. Set the following properties, for this element:

ul.li: Action to Greater than or Equal

helpTopic.h2: Create SCA Properties and assign them
helpTopic.p: In this section you will create SCA properties for the Modem and then assign them to the SCAPrimitives you created and defined above.

ol.li: Open Modem diagram.
Right click on Modem structure realization and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute KIPS.
Select KIPS and in the Properties View > SCA tab. Click Select type and choose SCA Primitive KIPS. Set the Value to 50.
Right click on the Modem structure realization and select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the property Throughput.
Select Throughput and in the Properties View > SCA tab. Click Select type and choose SCA Primitive Throughput. Set the Value to 100.

helpTopic.p: To ensure you have not introduced any errors, right click on Modem, on the diagram or in the Project Explorer, and select SCA Validate. Correct any errors.

A node is made of the set of devices under the control of a single Device Manager component. A node can contain one or more devices and their connections. One of the devices in a node must be an executable device.
The concept of a node is introduced by CX. The SCA equivalent of a node is the DCD.

ol.li: Create a new package under the Platform package and name it DecryptorNode.
Create a diagram in the DecryptorNode package called DecryptorNode.
In the Palette, expand the SCA Platform drawer.
Select the Node element and drop it on the diagram you created.
Name the element DecryptorNode.
Resize the node to make it large enough to contain the device.
In the Project Explorer select Modem structural realization and drag it onto DecryptorNode.
ol.br: This creates a device instance on the node.
ol.li: Resize and move the device instance as required.

helpTopic.p: Next you need to define a Device Manager, Domain Manager, File Manager, and Log for the node.
The SCA defines Core Framework elements that provide services to the application and platform:
These elements need to be configured on the node. Each node requires a Device Manager and the entire platform requires one Domain Manager. The File Manager and Log elements are optional.
These Core Framework elements are similar to components and devices - they have attributes and implementations.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, right click on the Platform package and from the popup menu, select Add CX > Component.
Name it, DeviceManager and set the Type to DeviceManager. Click Finish.
Add processor and OS dependencies from the SCADependencies diagram to the DeviceManager diagram. Using the Palette, create OS and Processor links.
Validate DeviceManager and correct any errors.
In the Project Explorer, right click on the Platform package and from the popup menu, select Add CX > Component.
Name the CF element DomainManager and set the Type to DomainManager. Click Finish.
Add Processor and OS dependencies from the SCADependencies diagram to the DomainManager diagram. Using the Palette, create OS and Processor links.
Validate DomainManager and correct any errors.

helpTopic.p: Next you must define the Domain Manager Descriptor for this Domain Manager. The Domain Manager Descriptor describes the services the Domain Manager connects to during startup.

ol.li: In the Palette, expand the SCA Platform drawer.
Select the Domain element and drop it onto the DomainManager diagram you have been using.
Change the name to myDomain.
In the Palette, select the Domain Dependency and link from myDomain to DomainManager. You can delete the label from this association if you want to.
In the Palette, select the DMD Service and drop this element onto the diagram.
Name this element LogService.
In the Palette, select the DMD Service Link and link from myDomain to LogService.
In the diagram, select LogService.
In the Properties View > SCA tab and configure the following mandatory properties:
Save the model.
In the Project Explorer, right click on the Platform package and from the popup menu, select Add CX > Component.
Name the service DomainLog and set the Type to Log. Click Finish.
Add processor and OS dependencies from the SCADependencies diagram to the DomainLog diagram. Using the Palette, draw OS and Processor links.
Validate DomainLog and correct any errors.

helpTopic.h2: Add Core Framework elements to the node
helpTopic.p: Now that you have created the elements and requirements of the node, you must now add them to the node.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select the DomainManager structure realization and drag it onto the DecryptorNode diagram.
Repeat for the Device Manager.
Repeat for the DomainLog.
Resize and move the DecryptorNode parts as desired.

helpTopic.p: The node has attributes that need to be defined. CX automatically determines the Device Manager for the node and updates appropriately. Using the namingservice property, you need to define the Domain Manager.

ol.li: Open the DecryptorNode diagram.
Select DecryptorNode.
In the Properties View > SCA tab.
Configure the Naming Service property to be the myDomain/DomainManager. This tells the Node how to find the DomainManager in the NamingService.
Save the model.

helpTopic.p: Validation will ensure that you haven't missed anything or introduced any errors to the node.

ol.li: In Project Explorer, select the DecryptorNode and from the right-click menu select SCA Validation.
If errors are returned, navigate to the error source and debug.

helpTopic.p: A platform is a set of nodes under the control of a single domain manager. A platform can contain one or more nodes,
A platform is a modeling entity introduced by CX. The SCA equivalent of the platform is the entire set of DCDs that comprise the Domain.

ol.li: Create a new diagram under the Platform package and name it Platform.
In the Palette, expand the SCA Platform drawer.
Select the Platform element and drop it onto the diagram.
Name the element CommunicatorPlatform.
Resize the element so it will hold the node.
In the Project Explorer, select the DecryptorNode you created and drag it onto the CommunicatorPlatform.
Validate CommunicatorPlatform and correct any errors.

helpTopic.h2: Add a Software Package Reference Dependency
helpTopic.p: A software package reference dependency specifies a dependency to a Software Package (SPD). This element is typically used for libraries needed by components.
The first step is to create the SoftPkg component:

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select the TutorialApplication package and create a package named CryptoLibImpl.
Right click on CryptoLib and add a Component Diagram named CryptoLib.
In the Palette, select Library and drop this element onto CryptoLib. Name the element CryptoLib.
With CryptoLib selected, in the Properties View > SCA tab and uncheck the SCA Compliant property.
In the Palette, select Implementation Artifact and drop this element onto the diagram. Name this element CryptoLibImpl.
Select CryptoLibImpl and in the Properties View > SCA tab. Set Code > File to cryptolib.so and Type to Shared Library.
Use the Palette to draw a Component Implementation link from the CryptoLibImpl implementation to the CryptoLib component.
From Project Explorer open the SCADependencies package, and add Linux and x86 to the CryptoLib diagram.
From the Palette, add OS and Processor links from CryptoLibImpl to Linux and x86.

helpTopic.p: The next step is to add a Resource Dependency:

From the Project Explorer drag the CryptoLib structure realization onto Decryptor.
From the SCA Application of the Palette drawer, select Resource Dependency and draw a link from the Decryptor_Impl to the CryptoLib library component. Name the link needsLibrary.

Validate the Decryptor package and correct any errors.
Save the model.

helpTopic.h2: Uses Devices and Uses Devices Dependencies
helpTopic.p: The uses device relationship describes the requirement of something from a device. It shows that a component needs the device. This relationship can be used to configure connections. In this relationship, the source is a component or device definition or implementation and the target is an allocation property on a device definition or implementation. Additionally, a uses device can depend on more than one allocation property.

ol.li: Open the CXTutorial_Model::TutorialApplication::Decryptor::Decryptor diagram.
In the Palette, expand the SCA Application drawer and select UsesDevice. Drop this onto the Decryptor diagram and name the element RequiredThroughput.
Select RequiredThroughput and in the Properties View > SCA tab. Set type to Throughput.
From SCA Application drawer, select UsesDevice Dependency and draw a link from the Decryptor component to the RequiredThroughput element. Name this element UsesThroughput.
In Project Explorer expand the SCAProperties package. Drag the SCA Primitive property Throughput onto the Decryptor diagram.
In the Palette select Property Dependency and draw a link from RequiredThroughput to the Throughput property. The label on this link is not used so you may delete it.
Select the Property Dependency and in the Properties View > SCA tab and set the value to 10.
Validate the Decryptor package and correct any errors.
Save the model.

helpTopic.p: We will run validation here to catch any errors that may have been introduced during modeling.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer select the top-level model element: CXTutorial_Model.
Right-click and select SCA Validation.
Fix any errors that are returned.
Save your model.

helpTopic.p: In this tutorial you completed the final steps of modeling. Your application and model are fully-defined and ready for the next phase of COE - implementing.

helpTopic.title: Tutorial 5: Implementing
helpTopic.p: Once your model has been created and validated, the next step is the implementation of your components and devices and the generation of descriptor files and source code. CX makes this possible with its powerful code and descriptor generation functionality.

The code and descriptor generation capabilities of CX leverage the complete configuration in the model to determine the optimal code to generate for the applications and the communication between the connected elements. All of the information in the model is analyzed to determine the most optimized way to generate the code.
In this tutorial, you will:
This tutorial assumes you have completed Tutorial 1, Tutorial 2, Tutorial 3, and Tutorial 4.
In the Project Explorer expand the project and model you defined in Tutorial 4.

CX generates the source code once for each component. The build configuration determines the build environment that will be generated and this determines how the source code is built. With CX you have the option to create a build configuration or use an existing configuration. In your model, a component can have one or more implementations; each of these implementations has a build configuration for a specific operating environment. Using the build configuration wizard, you specify General and SCA Domain build options. Each of these have Base and Local Values. The Base Values are read only. The Local Values can be overridden for each implementation.
Before being able to use a Build Configuration in your model you must import one:

ol.li: In the Project Explorer select the CXTutorial_Model model.
Right click and from the pop-up menu select Import Model Library
Select the Deployed Library checkbox.
Choose the required build configuration from the drop down. For the sake of example, this tutorial will use the eorb16-linux-gcc-x86 Build Configuration.

helpTopic.p: This will add a Package Import element into the model that will make the selected build configuration available for use in your model.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select the ModemImpl you created.
Right-click and from the pop-up menu, select Build Configuration.
Select General and from the Base Build Configuration drop-down list, select the eorb16-linux-gcc-x86::eorb16-linux-gcc-x86-build Build Configuration.
ol.p: The base values for this build configuration are loaded and are read only. In this tutorial you will not edit the base values, but you could optionally select the Local Values tab to configure additional properties for Modem_Impl.
ol.li: Click OK.
Repeat this for AssemblyControllerImpl, DecryptorImpl, and FilterImpl, assigning the same Build Configuration to each one.
Validate your model and correct any errors.
Save the model.

helpTopic.p: Note: for this tutorial it is assumed the CF elements and the CryptoLib binaries are provided to you. So you won't generate code for these elements.

If make is not in your path or you use a specific make, you need to specify the make location. The make location specifies location of the make application used to build applications. Note that this must be GNU Make version 3.81 or later to work correctly with the makefiles generated by productName.

ol.li: Open Window > Preferences and expand productName > Modeling.
Enter the location of your GNU Make binary into the Make location field.
Click OK.

helpTopic.p: The application/node determines which components/devices source code needs to be generated for.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select and right-click TutorialApplication. From the pop-up menu, select CX Generate > SCA Code.
In the Project Explorer select and right-click CommunicatorPlatform. From the pop-up menu, select CX Generate > SCA Code.

helpTopic.p: The generated code is added to the Project Explorer in a folder structure that includes the functional, component, target specific, and port code. A new Project is added to the Project Explorer for this tutorial called CXTutorial_Model_src. You can browse this source code in either the ProductName or C/C++ perspective.
To browse the source code, simply navigate the generated source folder and open files and folders.
The comps folder contains the source code for the components in the application.
The devs folder contains the source code for the devices in the application.
Under each component or device folder there is a worker folder. This contains the code that will hold your functional code.
The framework folder contains generic code used by components, devices and ports.
The ports folder contains the code for uses and provides ports.

The Worker code is populated from CX and contains gaps where your functional code is inserted. Although you edit the worker code using the CDT source code editor, on the actual source files, CX stores your functional code in the model so that it can always regenerate those source files. Using CX, you can easily edit the Worker code and Worker operations. Note that when you choose to edit any of the fragments of worker code, CX will first generate the source code file to be edited. If the relevant source code file has not been generated previously, CX will generate it for you before opening the CDT editor at the appropriate location in the file.

Each location in the worker source files that can be edited by the user is marked by special pairs of comments. You must enter your functional code between these marker comments so that CX can distinguish your code from generated code. This enables CX to extract your functional code from these source files and store it in the model. This allows CX to always regenerate the source code from the model. An example of these marker comments is shown below.

ol.li: Ensure you are in the ProductName perspective.
Open the Decryptor diagram and select Decryptor.

helpTopic.p: To edit the Worker.h file:

ol.li: Right click Decryptor and select Open Editor > Header.
This will generate the scxDecryptorWorker.h file and open the CDT editor on it, with the cursor placed between the marker comments.
Add the following: // worker header comment. This should be added between the markers, and then save the file.
When you saved the scxDecryptorWorker.h file, ProductName captures the changes you had made and stored them in the model.
Delete the scxDecryptorWorker.h file and go back to right click Decryptor and select Open Editor > Header again.
This will generate the scxDecryptorWorker.h file again and open the CDT editor on it again. This time you will see the modification that you previously made, and which ProductName has regenerated.

helpTopic.p: In addition to the above location, you may also edit code in the Worker.cpp file, using Open Editor > Implementation, and in the Worker class, using Open Editor > Class.

The worker's configure, query and runTest methods should be edited by right clicking on the appropriate SCA Property and selecting Open Editor. For example, to edit the Decryptor Worker's DECRYPT_KEY configure method, do the following:

ol.li: Select and right-click the Decryptor property DECRYPT_KEY and select Open Editor > Configure.
Add the following: execParams_.DECRYPT_KEY = DECRYPT_KEY.in();, save and close the file.
Select and right-click the Decryptor property DECRYPT_KEY and select Open Editor > Query.
Add the following: DECRYPT_KEY = execParams_.DECRYPT_KEY.c_str();, save and close the file.
Right click Decryptor and select CX Generate > SCA Code. This regenerates the code for the component.
Inspect the scxDecrytporWorker.cpp file and see the change you made is still there.

helpTopic.p: Other methods can be edited directly (i.e. start, stop, initialize, releaseObject). To edit these methods simply select them, right click and select Open Editor.

Every provides port operation is represented by a method in the worker. A port name on a component has to be unique. To ensure components can handle multiple provides ports of the same interface type CX names each method <port_name>_<method>. For example, to edit the Decryptor Worker's provides ports method, select and right-click the Decryptor::dataIn_pushEncryptedData() method and select Open Editor. This method is called when a pushEncryptedData message is received on the dataIn port.
Save the model.
In order to compile the source code, select or open the Make Targets view (to open, go to Window > Show View > Other).

ol.li: In the Make Targets view, double click on the all target to compile everything.
ol.br: The console view allows you to view the build progress. You should see the source code generated and compiled for the IDL, ports and the build target. The binaries should appear under subdirectories of the CXTutorial_Model_src/obj directory.

helpTopic.p: CX generates SCA-compliant XML descriptor files from the UML 2.0 model that you define. XML can be generated from Applications, Nodes, Platforms and individual component structure realizations. CX creates all the XML descriptor files as specified in the Domain Profile.
To generate the application XML, do the following:

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select TutorialApplication and from the pop-up menu select CX Generate > Descriptor(s).
ol.p: The files are generated and added to the CXTutorial_Model_src/descriptors folder.

helpTopic.p: CX generates the Software Assembly Descriptor for the application. It also generates the Software Component and Software Package Descriptors for each component contained in the application. If you have defined properties for the components, CX generates the Properties Descriptors, as well.
To generate the platform xml, do the following:

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, select CommunicatorPlatform and from the pop-up menu select CX Generate > Descriptor(s).

helpTopic.p: CX generates the Device Configuration Descriptor for all nodes in the platform. It also generates the Software Component and Software Package Descriptors for each device or Core Framework element contained in the node. If you have defined properties for the devices or Core Framework entities, CX generates the Property Descriptors, as well.

ProductName can be used to validate SCA XML descriptor files, whether they are generated from a ProductName model or not. To validate the SCA descriptors that were just generated off the CommunicatorPlatform and TutorialApplication, do the following:

ol.li: Select the CXTutorial_Model_src/descriptors folder.
Right click and select Validate.

helpTopic.p: This will result in 8 problem markers being created on some of the descriptor files. Each of these errors relates to a localfile name attribute referring to a file that does not exist. Each SPD file contains at least one implementation block which in turn references the actual executable or shared library file that it describes. When ProductName generates the descriptors and the binaries, it does not currently generate these filename references with full path information, which is why the SCA XML Validation raises these errors. These errors will be fixed in the following sections.
So far, we have generated code, and compiled it, to produce binaries for the following components:
It is assumed that the binaries for the other components are pre-existing, either from a Core Framework distribution or elsewhere:

This section describes how to model these pre-existing binaries so that they will get copied into the CXTutorial_Model_src project during generation. To do this we need to associate a Binary Configuration with the appropriate Component Implementation elements. A Binary Configuration is similar to a Build Configuration except instead of specifying how to generate and compile code, to produce the binary for the component, it specifies the location of a pre-existing binary for the component.

Before doing this we need to create a dummy cryptolib.so file. This file is required to satisfy the SPD validation and Core Framework runtime. However, since it only exists in order to demonstrate a modeling construct, it doesn't need to be a functional library.

ol.li: Right-click on the CXTutorial project and select New > File.
In the New File dialog, select the CXTutorial project.
Enter the File Name as cryptolib.so and click Finish.

helpTopic.p: Now create the Binary Configurations.

ol.li: In the Project Explorer, or on the DomainManager diagram, select the DomainManagerImpl element.
Right click and select Build Configuration....
In the Base Build Configuration drop down, select eorb16-linux-gcc-x86::eorb16-linux-gcc-x86-build (or the Build Configuration that describes your pre-existing binary the closest).
Check the Use Binary Configuration check box.

Click the Browse button on the Binary field and select your pre-existing DomainManager binary. Note you can browse for your binary either in the workspace or in the file system. Using a workspace URI, rather than a native file system URI, makes your model projects more portable between different workspaces.
Click OK.
Now select the DomainManager element, right-click and select CX Generate > Descriptor(s).
Expand CXTutorial_Model_src/obj/eorb16-linux-gcc-x86-tools/eorb16-linux-gcc-x86-build and you will see the generated DomainManager directory containing the copied DomainManager binary.

helpTopic.p: Repeat the above steps for the DeviceManager, DomainLog and cryptolib.so binaries.

Now that all of the binary files have been either compiled or copied into CXTutorial_Model_src/obj/..., the SCA XML validation errors can now be addressed. This is done by creating a symbolic link (or copy) of the binaries in the CXTutorial_Model_src/descriptors directory.

Note that in the steps below, the names of the <toolsdir> and <builddir> directories depends on which Build Configuration you have chosen. If you have used the eorb16-linux-gcc-x86 Build Configuration these directories will be named eorb16-linux-gcc-x86-tools and eorb16-linux-gcc-x86-build.
Also, depending on which Build Configuration you have chosen, the binary executable files may have an extension such as .vxe or .mod etc.

ol.li: Expand the CXTutorial_Model_src project.
Link or copy the following binary files into the descriptors directory:

helpTopic.p: Repeat the steps to validate the descriptors directory, and all of the XML errors should now be fixed, indicating that you now have a self consistent set of valid descriptors and binary files.
In this tutorial you have learned about code and descriptor generation. This final phase of the process shows how the model and its elements can be used to implement the principles of COE.

helpTopic.title: Tutorial 6: Deploying on a Spectra Core Framework

helpTopics.helpTopic:
Tutorial 6: Deploying on a Spectra Core Framework
This tutorial assumes you have completed Tutorial 1, Tutorial 2, Tutorial 3, Tutorial 4 and Tutorial 5.
In Tutorial 5 components were associated with implementations; build configurations were specified; domain descriptors and source code were generated.
In this tutorial, you will:
Amend components to make them deployable on Spectra Core Framework
Build the generated source code
Start an OE platform (created in Tutorial 3)
Load and run the Application (created in Tutorial 2)
Amending Components for Spectra CF
Throughout this section, it is assumed that you are working on Linux and you have e*ORB installed in $EORBHOME and Spectra Core Framework installed in $CFHOME.
Open the project and model
In the Project Explorer expand the project and model you worked with in Tutorial 5.
Adding Properties
To deploy an application successfully, the runtime must be able to match all Resource and Device properties. This step adds the properties to Spectra CX generated components and Spectra CF components to correctly setup for a successful application deployment.
Spectra CF Components
DeviceManager
DeviceManager requires os_name, processor and os_version properties. In addition for logging PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL is required.
Open the DeviceManager diagram
Right click on the DeviceManager component and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute os_name.
Select os_name and in the Properties View > SCA tab.
Click Select type and browse to SCA Primitive CXTutorial_Model > (SCALibrary) > os_name. Set the Value to Linux.
Right click on the DeviceManager component and select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute processor_name.
Select processor_name and in the Properties View > SCA tab.
Click Select type and browse to SCA Primitive CXTutorial_Model > (SCALibrary) > processor_name. Set the Value to x86.
Open the SCAPropertiesDiagram
In the Palette, expand the SCA Platform drawer.
In the Property Types drop-down list, select Primitive Property Type.
Drop this element onto the SCAPropertiesDiagram.
Name the property os_version.
In the Properties View > SCA tab.
Set the following attributes:
ID: DCE:cf250630-4ba8-11da-8cd6-0800200c9a66
Action: Equal
Kind: Allocation
Type: String
Right click on DeviceManager component and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute os_version.
Select os_version and in the Properties View > SCA tab. Click Type: and browse to SCA Primitive os_version.
Set the Value: field to 2.6.
Right click on the DeviceManager component and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL.
Select the PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL property.
In the Properties View > SCA tab, click Select type and browse to SCA Primitive CXTutorial_Model > (SCALibrary) > PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL.
In the Properties View > General tab, set the Multiplicity to *
In the Properties View > General tab, set the Default Value to 2,8
Save the model.
DomainManager
The DomainManager requires two properties to work with SpectraCX generated components. In addition, for logging PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL is required.
Threadpool Settings
Open the SCAPropertiesDiagram
In the Palette, expand the SCA Platform drawer.
In the Property Types drop-down list, select Primitive Property Type.
Drop this element onto the SCAPropertiesDiagram.
Name the property THREADPOOL_NO_POOL.
In the Properties View > SCA tab.
Set the following attributes:
ID: THREADPOOL_NO_POOL
Action: Equal
Kind: Exec
Type: Ulong
Open the DomainManager diagram.
Right click on DomainManager component and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute THREADPOOL_NO_POOL.
Select THREADPOOL_NO_POOL and in the Properties View > SCA tab. Click Type: and browse to SCA Primitive THREADPOOL_NO_POOL.
Set the Value: field to 1.
Save the model.
DomainManager domain profile
Open the SCAPropertiesDiagram
In the Palette, expand the SCA Platform drawer.
In the Property Types drop-down list, select Primitive Property Type.
Drop this element onto the SCAPropertiesDiagram.
Name the property DMD_FILENAME.
In the Properties View > SCA tab.
Set the following attributes:
ID: DMD_FILENAME
Action: Equal
Kind: Exec
Type: String
Open the DomainManager diagram.
Right click on DomainManager component and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute DMD_FILENAME.
Select DMD_FILENAME and in the Properties View > SCA tab. Click Type: and browse to SCA Primitive DMD_FILENAME.
Set the Value: field to /dmfs/DomainManager.dmd.xml
Save the model.
PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL
Right click on the DomainManager component and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL.
Select the PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL property.
In the Properties View > SCA tab, click Select type and browse to SCA Primitive CXTutorial_Model > (SCALibrary) > PRODUCER_LOG_LEVEL.
In the Properties View > General tab, set the Multiplicity to *
In the Properties View > General tab, set the Default Value to 2,8
Spectra CX Components
Modem
Open Modem diagram.
Right click on Modem structure realization and from the popup menu, select Add CX > SCA Property. Name the attribute os_version.
Select os_version and in the Properties View > SCA tab. Click Select type and browse to SCA Primitive os_version.
Set the Value: to 2.6.
Building Source Code
Your source code must be rebuilt after changes to generated components. Please refer back to Tutorial 5 Generate Code step for instructions on how to generate. After generation of source code, follow Tutorial 5 Compile the Source and Tutorial 5 Descriptor Generation again to ensure all binary and domain profiles are consistent with the new model changes for Spectra Core Framework deployment.
Testing the components
Before deploying your components they need to be tested. Spectra CX can generate tests for your components.
To configure your model for test generation:
In the Project Explorer, select the CXTutorial_Model model.
Right click and select Import Model Library....
Select the Deployed Library checkbox.
Choose the TargetLoader library from the drop down list and click OK.li>
In the Project Explorer, select the CXTutorial_Model model.
Right click and select Add CX > SCA Target Loader.
In the Project Explorer, select the SCATargetLoader.
In the Properties pane select the SCA tab and configure SCATargetLoader as follows:
Name: SCATargetLoader
Object Ref: corbaloc:iiop:1.1@<IP ADDRESS OR HOST NAME>:8277/TargetLoader
Timeout: 60000
To generate and run tests for your components:
Open the Modem diagram.
Drag the SCATargetLoader from the Project Explorer onto the diagram.
Select "Target Loader Dependency" from the palette.
Add a dependency from ModemImpl to SCATargetLoader.
Select the Modem structural realization.
Right click and select CX Generate -> Tests.
Run the $CFHOME/bin/TargetLoader binary in a terminal.
In the Project Explorer, select CXTutorial_Model_src/utests/tests/CXTutorial_Model/Platform/Modem/ModemImplSCATargetLoaderTest.java.
Right click and select Run As -> JUnit Test.
Repeat steps 1 to 4 for the DomainLog, Decryptor, Filter and AssemblyController.
To generate and run test suites for your assemblies:
In the Project Explorer, select CommunicatorPlatform.
Right click and select CX Generate -> Tests.
Run the $CFHOME/bin/TargetLoader binary in a terminal.
In the Project Explorer, select CXTutorial_Model_src/utests/tests/CXTutorial_Model/Platform/CommunicatorPlatformTestSuite.java.
Right click and select Run As -> JUnit Test.
The will run the tests for the Modem and the DomainLog.
Repeat this process for the TutorialApplication (TutorialApplicationTestSuite.java will run the tests for the Decryptor, the Filter and the AssemblyController).
Running OE Platform
In order to run the platform you will need to change directory into CXTutorial_Model_src/descriptors.
At the terminal prompt enter:
$CFHOME/bin/BootLoader -DCD_FILENAME DecryptorNode.dcd.xml -ORBInitRef NameService=corbaloc:iiop:1.1@ < IP ADDRESS OR HOST NAME > :2809/NameService
You should see output similar to the following, if not check your steps again.
$ cd ~/spectracx/workspace/Tutorial_Model_src/descriptors
$ /home/cf/spectracx/release/3.1-GA/oe/bin/BootLoader -DCD_FILENAME DecryptorNode.dcd.xml -ORBInitRef NameService=corbaloc:iiop:1.1@10.1.0.23:2809/NameService

-DEVICE_MGR_IOR IOR:010000001900000049444c3a43462f4465766963654d616e616765723a312e3000000000010000000000000044000000010101000a00000031302e312e302e3233001e9a2800000001921800654f52427a910020030000000e4465766963654d616e616765720000040000000f00000000000000
ORB Args:

-ORBInitRef NameService=corbaloc:iiop:1.1@10.1.0.23:2809/NameService
Or:
-ORBInitRef
NameService=IOR:010000002800000049444c3a6f6d672e6f72672f436f734e616d696e672f4e616d696e67436f6e746578743a312e3000010000000000000050000000010101000a00000031302e312e302e323300f90a3200000001820a00654f5242000000000e446f6d61696e4d616e6167657200000b0000004e414d494e475f504f410000020000003000000000000000
DomainManager waiting for requests ....
Loading and Running Application
In order to run an application you need to add a Monitor to the model.
In the Project Explorer, select the CXTutorial_Model model.
Right click and select Add CX > Monitor
New Monitor Wizard will appear, set
Name: Monitor
Domain Manager: myDomain/DomainManager
Naming Service: corbaloc:iiop:1.1@<IP ADDRESS OR HOST NAME>:2809/NameService
Click the Finish button.
Select the new Monitor object in CXTutorial_Model.
Right click Monitor > Open SCA Monitor
The Monitor view will appear showing Control and Deployment panes. The view will contain running OE components (DeviceManager, DomainManager, ModemDevice).
In the Control pane, right click Application Folder > Install Application Factory
The Enter SAD window will appear. Enter the path to the SAD file, which is /dmfs/TutorialApplication.sad.xml
Click OK.
In the Control window you will see the TutorialApplication application factory deployed.
Right click on the TutorialApplication factory and select Create Application
Enter app1 as the application name, and click OK
The new application instance app1 will show up in the Control window and, in the Deployment window, you will see its constituent resources executing on the Modem device.
Right clicking on app1 will let you control the lifecycle of your application instance. There are options to Start, Stop and Release your instance.
